WEBVTT

00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:00.300 align:middle line:90%


00:00:00.300 --> 00:00:01.550 align:middle line:90%
DIANE DALLIS-COMENTALE: Hello.

00:00:01.550 --> 00:00:02.050 align:middle line:90%
OK.

00:00:02.050 --> 00:00:03.710 align:middle line:90%
Just checking.

00:00:03.710 --> 00:00:05.310 align:middle line:90%
Welcome everyone.

00:00:05.310 --> 00:00:07.050 align:middle line:90%
Good afternoon.

00:00:07.050 --> 00:00:11.390 align:middle line:84%
I'm Diane Dallis-Comentale,
Ruth Lilly Dean of IU Libraries.

00:00:11.390 --> 00:00:13.550 align:middle line:84%
Indiana University
has championed

00:00:13.550 --> 00:00:16.280 align:middle line:84%
libraries and archives
of diverse collections

00:00:16.280 --> 00:00:18.290 align:middle line:84%
which have been
developed over centuries

00:00:18.290 --> 00:00:20.840 align:middle line:84%
by expert librarians,
researchers, archivists,

00:00:20.840 --> 00:00:22.070 align:middle line:90%
and curators.

00:00:22.070 --> 00:00:24.440 align:middle line:84%
As a librarian, I
have the privilege

00:00:24.440 --> 00:00:26.480 align:middle line:84%
of leading one of the
top research library

00:00:26.480 --> 00:00:28.680 align:middle line:90%
systems in North America.

00:00:28.680 --> 00:00:31.940 align:middle line:84%
My role requires me to
simultaneously consider

00:00:31.940 --> 00:00:35.000 align:middle line:84%
the past and the future, and
constantly keep those things

00:00:35.000 --> 00:00:36.350 align:middle line:90%
in the balance.

00:00:36.350 --> 00:00:39.050 align:middle line:84%
I ask that we pause
for a moment to think

00:00:39.050 --> 00:00:41.300 align:middle line:84%
about all that has
come before us,

00:00:41.300 --> 00:00:44.660 align:middle line:84%
and all those who made it
possible for us to be here,

00:00:44.660 --> 00:00:46.190 align:middle line:90%
together, today.

00:00:46.190 --> 00:00:49.370 align:middle line:84%
Indiana University was built
on Indigenous homelands

00:00:49.370 --> 00:00:50.450 align:middle line:90%
and resources.

00:00:50.450 --> 00:00:52.550 align:middle line:84%
With deep respect
and appreciation,

00:00:52.550 --> 00:00:56.340 align:middle line:84%
I acknowledge the Indigenous
nations' communities, families,

00:00:56.340 --> 00:01:00.780 align:middle line:84%
and especially those of the
Miami, Delaware, Potawatomi,

00:01:00.780 --> 00:01:02.340 align:middle line:90%
and Shawnee people.

00:01:02.340 --> 00:01:04.830 align:middle line:84%
The Foundation of our
state and our University

00:01:04.830 --> 00:01:08.280 align:middle line:84%
was built on unceded land
by indentured laborers,

00:01:08.280 --> 00:01:11.670 align:middle line:84%
immigrants, and many people
who endured and struggled

00:01:11.670 --> 00:01:14.820 align:middle line:84%
those whose names
and lives have often

00:01:14.820 --> 00:01:17.160 align:middle line:90%
been forgotten by history.

00:01:17.160 --> 00:01:20.640 align:middle line:84%
With this in mind, before
our program starts,

00:01:20.640 --> 00:01:23.400 align:middle line:84%
I hope that you consider the
opportunity and privilege we

00:01:23.400 --> 00:01:26.050 align:middle line:90%
all share in being here today.

00:01:26.050 --> 00:01:28.770 align:middle line:84%
All who have come
before us, all who

00:01:28.770 --> 00:01:32.160 align:middle line:84%
have made it possible
to be here today,

00:01:32.160 --> 00:01:36.600 align:middle line:84%
open to a conversation
across many generations

00:01:36.600 --> 00:01:39.430 align:middle line:84%
and with many new
ideas coming together.

00:01:39.430 --> 00:01:41.790 align:middle line:84%
This is a privilege
we share, and I really

00:01:41.790 --> 00:01:43.920 align:middle line:84%
appreciate your thoughts
about that as you go

00:01:43.920 --> 00:01:45.850 align:middle line:90%
through the rest of your day.

00:01:45.850 --> 00:01:49.020 align:middle line:84%
So on behalf of
our partners, I am

00:01:49.020 --> 00:01:52.950 align:middle line:84%
thrilled by your interest in
the significance of archives

00:01:52.950 --> 00:01:54.840 align:middle line:84%
and the role of the
national government.

00:01:54.840 --> 00:01:58.500 align:middle line:84%
It is an honor for IU to host
this discussion as we kick off

00:01:58.500 --> 00:02:01.710 align:middle line:84%
American Archives Month
as well as a month

00:02:01.710 --> 00:02:04.150 align:middle line:84%
celebrating archives of
the state of Indiana.

00:02:04.150 --> 00:02:07.770 align:middle line:84%
Thanks to a formal
proclamation by our governor.

00:02:07.770 --> 00:02:10.979 align:middle line:84%
Our partners for this gathering
are listed on the screen above.

00:02:10.979 --> 00:02:12.840 align:middle line:84%
Though, I am specifically
calling attention

00:02:12.840 --> 00:02:14.490 align:middle line:84%
to our friends at
the Luddy School

00:02:14.490 --> 00:02:17.310 align:middle line:84%
of Informatics Department
of Information and Library

00:02:17.310 --> 00:02:20.220 align:middle line:84%
Science, the Hamilton
Lugar School of Global

00:02:20.220 --> 00:02:23.250 align:middle line:84%
and International Studies,
and the Paul O'Neill

00:02:23.250 --> 00:02:26.040 align:middle line:84%
School of Public and
Environmental Affairs.

00:02:26.040 --> 00:02:30.345 align:middle line:84%
If you are here as part of
the fall 2023 Themester, Lux

00:02:30.345 --> 00:02:33.390 align:middle line:84%
et Veritas, you deserve
a special welcome.

00:02:33.390 --> 00:02:35.790 align:middle line:84%
Thank you to the College
of Arts and Sciences

00:02:35.790 --> 00:02:37.920 align:middle line:84%
for more than a
decade of engaged

00:02:37.920 --> 00:02:41.460 align:middle line:84%
learning through the exceptional
issues based Themester

00:02:41.460 --> 00:02:43.620 align:middle line:90%
teaching and programming.

00:02:43.620 --> 00:02:47.790 align:middle line:84%
It turns out that this
year's Themester theme, light

00:02:47.790 --> 00:02:50.400 align:middle line:84%
and truth, was quite
inspirational to my colleague

00:02:50.400 --> 00:02:52.830 align:middle line:84%
Dina Kellams, Director
of University Archives,

00:02:52.830 --> 00:02:56.190 align:middle line:84%
and the incredible team
of archivists she leads.

00:02:56.190 --> 00:02:58.530 align:middle line:84%
When they first began
discussing and planning

00:02:58.530 --> 00:03:06.350 align:middle line:84%
this year's activities,
they knew right away

00:03:06.350 --> 00:03:09.470 align:middle line:84%
that the person they
wanted to have come,

00:03:09.470 --> 00:03:11.630 align:middle line:84%
who could best
illustrate and illuminate

00:03:11.630 --> 00:03:16.190 align:middle line:84%
how important archives are,
is our former Archivist

00:03:16.190 --> 00:03:18.710 align:middle line:84%
of the United States,
David Ferriero.

00:03:18.710 --> 00:03:20.810 align:middle line:84%
In a moment I will
hand over the stage

00:03:20.810 --> 00:03:22.970 align:middle line:84%
to Sara Stefani one
of the IU Library's

00:03:22.970 --> 00:03:25.640 align:middle line:84%
many outstanding archivists,
who will be moderating

00:03:25.640 --> 00:03:27.320 align:middle line:90%
this discussion today.

00:03:27.320 --> 00:03:28.880 align:middle line:90%
Sara is the modical--

00:03:28.880 --> 00:03:30.860 align:middle line:84%
political-- modern--
I'm so sorry.

00:03:30.860 --> 00:03:33.560 align:middle line:84%
Modern Political Papers
Archivist and she

00:03:33.560 --> 00:03:36.050 align:middle line:84%
joined the IU Libraries
in 2018 to work

00:03:36.050 --> 00:03:40.460 align:middle line:84%
on the papers of the longtime
Indiana Senator, Richard Lugar.

00:03:40.460 --> 00:03:43.670 align:middle line:84%
Sara received her doctorate
from Yale University

00:03:43.670 --> 00:03:46.790 align:middle line:84%
in Slavic languages
and literature.

00:03:46.790 --> 00:03:50.450 align:middle line:84%
She oversees our collections
of papers from Congresswoman,

00:03:50.450 --> 00:03:54.290 align:middle line:84%
Jill Long Thompson, Senator
Birch Bayh, and Congressman Lee

00:03:54.290 --> 00:03:56.390 align:middle line:90%
Hamilton, among many others.

00:03:56.390 --> 00:03:59.360 align:middle line:84%
She is a member of the steering
committee of the Congressional

00:03:59.360 --> 00:04:03.480 align:middle line:84%
Papers Section of the
American Society of Archivist,

00:04:03.480 --> 00:04:06.600 align:middle line:84%
and the president of the
Association of Centers

00:04:06.600 --> 00:04:08.460 align:middle line:90%
for the Study of Congress.

00:04:08.460 --> 00:04:11.400 align:middle line:84%
Sarah will be leading the
question and answer session

00:04:11.400 --> 00:04:14.670 align:middle line:84%
with our distinguished
guest, David Ferriero, who

00:04:14.670 --> 00:04:17.160 align:middle line:84%
served as the 10th archivist
of the United States

00:04:17.160 --> 00:04:20.880 align:middle line:90%
from 2009 through April 2022.

00:04:20.880 --> 00:04:24.330 align:middle line:84%
President Barack Obama
nominated Mr Ferriero,

00:04:24.330 --> 00:04:26.370 align:middle line:84%
who was confirmed
by the US Senate

00:04:26.370 --> 00:04:29.130 align:middle line:90%
and sworn in November of 2020--

00:04:29.130 --> 00:04:30.870 align:middle line:90%
sorry, 2009.

00:04:30.870 --> 00:04:34.230 align:middle line:84%
As archivist, Mr Ferriero
oversaw the addition

00:04:34.230 --> 00:04:37.170 align:middle line:84%
of three new
presidential libraries

00:04:37.170 --> 00:04:41.940 align:middle line:84%
to the National Archives
and Records Administration

00:04:41.940 --> 00:04:45.090 align:middle line:90%
Presidential Library systems.

00:04:45.090 --> 00:04:47.010 align:middle line:84%
Before leading the
National Archives,

00:04:47.010 --> 00:04:50.580 align:middle line:84%
Mr Ferriero served as
Andrew W. Mellon, director

00:04:50.580 --> 00:04:52.200 align:middle line:90%
of New York Public Library.

00:04:52.200 --> 00:04:53.970 align:middle line:84%
He was part of the
leadership team

00:04:53.970 --> 00:04:58.050 align:middle line:84%
responsible for integrating the
four research libraries and 87

00:04:58.050 --> 00:05:01.390 align:middle line:84%
branches to create the
largest public library

00:05:01.390 --> 00:05:04.540 align:middle line:84%
system in the United States
and one of the largest research

00:05:04.540 --> 00:05:06.100 align:middle line:90%
libraries in the world.

00:05:06.100 --> 00:05:10.330 align:middle line:84%
Mr Ferriero served in
top leadership positions

00:05:10.330 --> 00:05:13.390 align:middle line:84%
in two of the nation's
highly ranked universities,

00:05:13.390 --> 00:05:16.190 align:middle line:84%
the Massachusetts Institute
of Technology in Cambridge,

00:05:16.190 --> 00:05:20.200 align:middle line:84%
Massachusetts, and Duke
University in Durham, North

00:05:20.200 --> 00:05:21.070 align:middle line:90%
Carolina.

00:05:21.070 --> 00:05:25.570 align:middle line:84%
Mr Ferriero earned bachelor's
degrees and master's degrees

00:05:25.570 --> 00:05:28.420 align:middle line:84%
in English Literature from
Northeastern University

00:05:28.420 --> 00:05:32.080 align:middle line:84%
in Boston and a master's degree
from Simmons College of Library

00:05:32.080 --> 00:05:34.510 align:middle line:84%
and Information
Science in Boston.

00:05:34.510 --> 00:05:38.050 align:middle line:84%
Mr Ferriero also served as
a Navy hospital corpsman

00:05:38.050 --> 00:05:39.580 align:middle line:90%
during the Vietnam War.

00:05:39.580 --> 00:05:43.660 align:middle line:84%
Before we jump into
the Q&A our moderator,

00:05:43.660 --> 00:05:46.840 align:middle line:84%
Sara Stefani has a
few details regarding

00:05:46.840 --> 00:05:48.470 align:middle line:90%
audience participation.

00:05:48.470 --> 00:05:50.290 align:middle line:84%
And I'm going to
hand things over

00:05:50.290 --> 00:05:52.360 align:middle line:90%
to Sarah's very capable hands.

00:05:52.360 --> 00:05:54.250 align:middle line:84%
And I sincerely
appreciate all of you

00:05:54.250 --> 00:05:55.450 align:middle line:90%
being in attendance today.

00:05:55.450 --> 00:05:56.670 align:middle line:90%
Thank you.

00:05:56.670 --> 00:06:00.170 align:middle line:90%
[APPLAUSE]

00:06:00.170 --> 00:06:03.670 align:middle line:90%


00:06:03.670 --> 00:06:05.590 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Hello, everyone.

00:06:05.590 --> 00:06:08.680 align:middle line:84%
I want to thank everyone
for coming today.

00:06:08.680 --> 00:06:12.730 align:middle line:84%
As Diane mentioned,
this is a celebration

00:06:12.730 --> 00:06:15.280 align:middle line:90%
of National Archives Month.

00:06:15.280 --> 00:06:20.710 align:middle line:84%
And also, this particular month
of October 2023, Governor Eric

00:06:20.710 --> 00:06:23.680 align:middle line:84%
Holcomb has decreed as
Indiana Archives Month.

00:06:23.680 --> 00:06:26.230 align:middle line:84%
So of course, there's
no better person

00:06:26.230 --> 00:06:28.390 align:middle line:84%
to have come to
talk about archives

00:06:28.390 --> 00:06:32.650 align:middle line:84%
than David Ferriero, the 10th
archivist of the United States.

00:06:32.650 --> 00:06:36.130 align:middle line:84%
And as far as audience
participation goes,

00:06:36.130 --> 00:06:39.430 align:middle line:84%
we will have a sing
along a little bit later.

00:06:39.430 --> 00:06:40.930 align:middle line:90%
No I'm just kidding.

00:06:40.930 --> 00:06:46.180 align:middle line:84%
So essentially, what we
plan to do today is David

00:06:46.180 --> 00:06:49.510 align:middle line:84%
and I will have a Q&A
session of our own

00:06:49.510 --> 00:06:52.370 align:middle line:84%
but possibly even
just a conversation.

00:06:52.370 --> 00:06:56.903 align:middle line:84%
I mean, we kind of hope
that this will be a--

00:06:56.903 --> 00:06:57.820 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Loose.

00:06:57.820 --> 00:06:59.237 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: A
loose conversation

00:06:59.237 --> 00:07:01.960 align:middle line:90%
that's of benefit to everybody.

00:07:01.960 --> 00:07:05.560 align:middle line:84%
But also there are
pre-selected or-- sorry,

00:07:05.560 --> 00:07:07.540 align:middle line:90%
pre-submitted questions.

00:07:07.540 --> 00:07:09.610 align:middle line:90%
I think most of you who RSVP'd--

00:07:09.610 --> 00:07:11.800 align:middle line:90%
or all of you who are RSVP'd--

00:07:11.800 --> 00:07:16.060 align:middle line:84%
received a link to potentially
submit questions ahead of time.

00:07:16.060 --> 00:07:21.260 align:middle line:84%
If you didn't submit any
questions, that's fine.

00:07:21.260 --> 00:07:22.600 align:middle line:90%
You may not have had any.

00:07:22.600 --> 00:07:26.110 align:middle line:84%
But during the course
of our conversation

00:07:26.110 --> 00:07:28.160 align:middle line:90%
questions may arise.

00:07:28.160 --> 00:07:30.190 align:middle line:84%
And this is why I
think all of you

00:07:30.190 --> 00:07:33.640 align:middle line:84%
have a note card and
a writing utensil.

00:07:33.640 --> 00:07:37.750 align:middle line:84%
And so please feel free to
write down any questions

00:07:37.750 --> 00:07:39.010 align:middle line:90%
that you may have.

00:07:39.010 --> 00:07:42.310 align:middle line:90%
And at approximately 4:45--

00:07:42.310 --> 00:07:44.470 align:middle line:84%
so maybe in about
a half an hour--

00:07:44.470 --> 00:07:46.570 align:middle line:84%
my colleagues at the
University Archives,

00:07:46.570 --> 00:07:49.480 align:middle line:84%
Dina Kellams and Carrie
Schweer, will come by

00:07:49.480 --> 00:07:51.340 align:middle line:90%
and collect your note cards.

00:07:51.340 --> 00:07:56.210 align:middle line:84%
And then I will hand the
floor over to your questions,

00:07:56.210 --> 00:07:59.090 align:middle line:84%
meaning that I'll take the
cards and read them all out.

00:07:59.090 --> 00:08:02.420 align:middle line:84%
So we will have your
input and the things

00:08:02.420 --> 00:08:03.720 align:middle line:90%
that interest you all.

00:08:03.720 --> 00:08:07.670 align:middle line:84%
So with that, I
guess we will start.

00:08:07.670 --> 00:08:11.690 align:middle line:84%
Actually, my first
question is unplanned

00:08:11.690 --> 00:08:13.250 align:middle line:84%
because it's
something that I just

00:08:13.250 --> 00:08:19.400 align:middle line:84%
learned right at the beginning
of this event, which is--

00:08:19.400 --> 00:08:20.790 align:middle line:84%
David, would you
like to tell us.

00:08:20.790 --> 00:08:23.780 align:middle line:84%
So as soon as you
came into the room,

00:08:23.780 --> 00:08:25.910 align:middle line:90%
you recognized these murals.

00:08:25.910 --> 00:08:30.050 align:middle line:84%
And you asked, are these
Thomas Hart Benton?

00:08:30.050 --> 00:08:31.250 align:middle line:90%
And why did you ask that?

00:08:31.250 --> 00:08:33.870 align:middle line:90%
What prompted you?

00:08:33.870 --> 00:08:36.770 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: Because
I recognized his style.

00:08:36.770 --> 00:08:41.929 align:middle line:84%
And a wonderful story about
Harry S. Truman Presidential

00:08:41.929 --> 00:08:47.120 align:middle line:84%
Library, where we have
a Thomas Hart Benton.

00:08:47.120 --> 00:08:51.740 align:middle line:84%
And Benton painted it while
Harry was still alive.

00:08:51.740 --> 00:08:53.750 align:middle line:84%
And we have
wonderful photographs

00:08:53.750 --> 00:08:59.840 align:middle line:84%
in the Library of Benton
on a ladder painting

00:08:59.840 --> 00:09:03.920 align:middle line:84%
next to Harry Truman on the
ladder painting a cloud.

00:09:03.920 --> 00:09:05.750 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:09:05.750 --> 00:09:09.470 align:middle line:84%
And we also have wonderful
photographs of Benton,

00:09:09.470 --> 00:09:13.130 align:middle line:84%
after Harry left, painting
over what Harry did.

00:09:13.130 --> 00:09:16.620 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:09:16.620 --> 00:09:19.817 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: So
essentially erasing history.

00:09:19.817 --> 00:09:21.150 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: It's underneath.

00:09:21.150 --> 00:09:22.170 align:middle line:90%
It's underneath.

00:09:22.170 --> 00:09:24.810 align:middle line:90%
It's still there.

00:09:24.810 --> 00:09:27.450 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: So my first
question, essentially,

00:09:27.450 --> 00:09:30.640 align:middle line:84%
was to ask you about being
the archivist of the United

00:09:30.640 --> 00:09:33.600 align:middle line:84%
States, which later
I'm going to follow up

00:09:33.600 --> 00:09:37.200 align:middle line:84%
to ask you to explain to the
audience what a Presidential

00:09:37.200 --> 00:09:38.070 align:middle line:90%
Library is.

00:09:38.070 --> 00:09:43.320 align:middle line:84%
But first let me ask you--
just for our general crowd--

00:09:43.320 --> 00:09:45.540 align:middle line:84%
can you explain a
little bit of what

00:09:45.540 --> 00:09:49.507 align:middle line:84%
does it mean to be the
archivist of the United States?

00:09:49.507 --> 00:09:51.840 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: A lot of
things that they didn't tell me

00:09:51.840 --> 00:09:53.137 align:middle line:90%
during the interview process.

00:09:53.137 --> 00:09:53.970 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Right.

00:09:53.970 --> 00:09:55.443 align:middle line:84%
Or in library
school, I'm assuming.

00:09:55.443 --> 00:09:56.610 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Forget that.

00:09:56.610 --> 00:09:56.970 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah, forget that.

00:09:56.970 --> 00:09:57.360 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHS]

00:09:57.360 --> 00:09:58.235 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Yeah.

00:09:58.235 --> 00:09:58.740 align:middle line:90%
Right.

00:09:58.740 --> 00:10:01.440 align:middle line:84%
The Archivist of
the United States

00:10:01.440 --> 00:10:07.110 align:middle line:84%
is responsible for overseeing
the creation, management,

00:10:07.110 --> 00:10:12.180 align:middle line:84%
and access to the
records created

00:10:12.180 --> 00:10:13.380 align:middle line:90%
by the federal government.

00:10:13.380 --> 00:10:14.490 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: OK.

00:10:14.490 --> 00:10:18.460 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: To follow a
prescribed set of laws, Federal

00:10:18.460 --> 00:10:20.050 align:middle line:84%
Records Act,
Presidential Records

00:10:20.050 --> 00:10:22.390 align:middle line:84%
Act, that kind of lay
down the law about how

00:10:22.390 --> 00:10:24.280 align:middle line:90%
things should work.

00:10:24.280 --> 00:10:36.220 align:middle line:84%
And provide access to the papers
of the government in order

00:10:36.220 --> 00:10:38.560 align:middle line:84%
for the American people
to hold their government

00:10:38.560 --> 00:10:42.130 align:middle line:84%
accountable for its actions
and to learn from our past.

00:10:42.130 --> 00:10:43.210 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: OK.

00:10:43.210 --> 00:10:45.978 align:middle line:84%
So how does one become the
Archivist of the United States.

00:10:45.978 --> 00:10:48.520 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: Well there was
this ad in the New York Times.

00:10:48.520 --> 00:10:48.820 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:10:48.820 --> 00:10:51.100 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: I was going
to say, I'm an archivist

00:10:51.100 --> 00:10:53.860 align:middle line:84%
and I want to be the Archivist
of the United States someday.

00:10:53.860 --> 00:10:55.240 align:middle line:90%
So.

00:10:55.240 --> 00:10:57.310 align:middle line:90%
Yeah, do I check Indeed or?

00:10:57.310 --> 00:10:58.810 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: It
was very strange.

00:10:58.810 --> 00:11:02.710 align:middle line:84%
I was at the New
York Public Library

00:11:02.710 --> 00:11:08.470 align:middle line:84%
and what looks like a very
cushy job from this perspective.

00:11:08.470 --> 00:11:11.050 align:middle line:84%
I had a wonderful
office on Fifth Avenue

00:11:11.050 --> 00:11:12.900 align:middle line:90%
with a lion outside my window.

00:11:12.900 --> 00:11:14.200 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Ooh.

00:11:14.200 --> 00:11:19.140 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: And a Friday
afternoon in April of whatever,

00:11:19.140 --> 00:11:21.240 align:middle line:90%
2009.

00:11:21.240 --> 00:11:23.070 align:middle line:84%
My assistant came in
and said the White

00:11:23.070 --> 00:11:24.420 align:middle line:90%
House is on the phone.

00:11:24.420 --> 00:11:25.672 align:middle line:90%
So I got on the phone.

00:11:25.672 --> 00:11:26.880 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Was it April 1?

00:11:26.880 --> 00:11:27.570 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: No, it wasn't.

00:11:27.570 --> 00:11:28.620 align:middle line:90%
[SUBDUED LAUGHTER]

00:11:28.620 --> 00:11:31.590 align:middle line:90%
It was around Patriots Day.

00:11:31.590 --> 00:11:34.720 align:middle line:84%
So it was like the
middle of the month.

00:11:34.720 --> 00:11:37.170 align:middle line:90%
So I got on the phone, Hello.

00:11:37.170 --> 00:11:40.530 align:middle line:84%
And this 12-year-old, who
was working on appointments

00:11:40.530 --> 00:11:43.080 align:middle line:90%
for the president, said--

00:11:43.080 --> 00:11:45.847 align:middle line:84%
I guess I wasn't enthusiastic
enough because he said--

00:11:45.847 --> 00:11:48.180 align:middle line:84%
aren't you surprised to be
getting a call from the White

00:11:48.180 --> 00:11:48.750 align:middle line:90%
House?

00:11:48.750 --> 00:11:50.493 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:11:50.493 --> 00:11:51.240 align:middle line:90%
Ah.

00:11:51.240 --> 00:11:52.740 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:11:52.740 --> 00:11:55.470 align:middle line:84%
So we moved beyond
that, and he said

00:11:55.470 --> 00:11:57.990 align:middle line:84%
that, I'm calling
because we're looking

00:11:57.990 --> 00:12:01.830 align:middle line:84%
at for the position of
archivist of the United States.

00:12:01.830 --> 00:12:03.930 align:middle line:84%
So this is a
presidential appointment.

00:12:03.930 --> 00:12:07.860 align:middle line:84%
And my sense of things
at that point-- and even

00:12:07.860 --> 00:12:11.610 align:middle line:84%
now-- is that presidential
appointments are usually

00:12:11.610 --> 00:12:15.060 align:middle line:84%
someone who gave a lot of
money to the campaign that

00:12:15.060 --> 00:12:18.640 align:middle line:84%
elected the president, or is
a friend of the president,

00:12:18.640 --> 00:12:21.580 align:middle line:84%
but doesn't know anything
about the business

00:12:21.580 --> 00:12:24.170 align:middle line:90%
of that particular position.

00:12:24.170 --> 00:12:26.110 align:middle line:84%
So why on Earth are
you calling me--

00:12:26.110 --> 00:12:27.610 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:12:27.610 --> 00:12:29.530 align:middle line:84%
--who knows the
business and doesn't

00:12:29.530 --> 00:12:30.830 align:middle line:90%
meet those other criteria?

00:12:30.830 --> 00:12:33.287 align:middle line:90%
So he couldn't answer that.

00:12:33.287 --> 00:12:35.120 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Did you
actually ask him that?

00:12:35.120 --> 00:12:35.912 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: No.

00:12:35.912 --> 00:12:36.460 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:12:36.460 --> 00:12:38.290 align:middle line:84%
I said, I'm very
flattered, but you're

00:12:38.290 --> 00:12:41.230 align:middle line:84%
looking at the wrong
person and made it clear

00:12:41.230 --> 00:12:43.090 align:middle line:84%
that this was the end
of the conversation.

00:12:43.090 --> 00:12:44.980 align:middle line:84%
And he said, well,
would you think about it

00:12:44.980 --> 00:12:47.680 align:middle line:84%
over the weekend, and
we'll talk again on Monday.

00:12:47.680 --> 00:12:49.010 align:middle line:90%
And I said, sure.

00:12:49.010 --> 00:12:51.045 align:middle line:90%
So he called Monday morning.

00:12:51.045 --> 00:12:52.420 align:middle line:84%
And we had the
same conversation.

00:12:52.420 --> 00:12:55.060 align:middle line:84%
And 10 minutes later
an adult called.

00:12:55.060 --> 00:12:59.530 align:middle line:84%
The poor kid, Kyle Watkins, was
an undergraduate at Georgetown

00:12:59.530 --> 00:13:01.480 align:middle line:90%
working on appointments.

00:13:01.480 --> 00:13:02.770 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Oh.

00:13:02.770 --> 00:13:04.270 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: He
wasn't in charge,

00:13:04.270 --> 00:13:07.780 align:middle line:84%
but he was the one who did
the research that found me.

00:13:07.780 --> 00:13:08.680 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Oh-ho.

00:13:08.680 --> 00:13:10.180 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: So
he got the honor

00:13:10.180 --> 00:13:13.510 align:middle line:84%
of calling me to tell me all
this, and I treated him poorly.

00:13:13.510 --> 00:13:15.740 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:13:15.740 --> 00:13:17.980 align:middle line:84%
So 10 minutes later
an adult called

00:13:17.980 --> 00:13:19.630 align:middle line:84%
and asked if he could
come to New York

00:13:19.630 --> 00:13:20.890 align:middle line:90%
and talk to me about the job.

00:13:20.890 --> 00:13:24.880 align:middle line:84%
And that week Tom
Wheeler, who turned out

00:13:24.880 --> 00:13:28.780 align:middle line:84%
to be the director
of the FCC later,

00:13:28.780 --> 00:13:31.720 align:middle line:84%
came and talked about what
the president was looking

00:13:31.720 --> 00:13:35.500 align:middle line:84%
for in the new archivist, and
how important the archives was

00:13:35.500 --> 00:13:37.870 align:middle line:84%
going to be in the
administration's

00:13:37.870 --> 00:13:41.740 align:middle line:90%
open government initiative.

00:13:41.740 --> 00:13:43.900 align:middle line:84%
And the more he talked,
the more excited

00:13:43.900 --> 00:13:46.090 align:middle line:90%
I got about the potential.

00:13:46.090 --> 00:13:47.860 align:middle line:84%
And knowing that I
know the business,

00:13:47.860 --> 00:13:51.730 align:middle line:84%
I was responsible for archives
at MIT, and Duke, and the New

00:13:51.730 --> 00:13:52.960 align:middle line:90%
York Public Library.

00:13:52.960 --> 00:13:56.032 align:middle line:84%
So it's not as if I
didn't know the business.

00:13:56.032 --> 00:13:57.490 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Right,
because people

00:13:57.490 --> 00:13:59.662 align:middle line:84%
have pointed out that
you're the first librarian.

00:13:59.662 --> 00:14:01.120 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO:
Very controversial.

00:14:01.120 --> 00:14:02.830 align:middle line:84%
Let me tell you,
very controversial.

00:14:02.830 --> 00:14:04.460 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: For those of you
who aren't in the business--

00:14:04.460 --> 00:14:05.543 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Oh my god.

00:14:05.543 --> 00:14:07.840 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: It actually
is kind of controversial.

00:14:07.840 --> 00:14:10.007 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: Yeah there's
a woman named Harriet--

00:14:10.007 --> 00:14:12.700 align:middle line:84%
who I'm still looking for-- when
my nomination was announced,

00:14:12.700 --> 00:14:14.230 align:middle line:90%
who said on some listserv--

00:14:14.230 --> 00:14:17.092 align:middle line:84%
I can't remember which one it
was-- he's only a librarian.

00:14:17.092 --> 00:14:17.842 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Ooh.

00:14:17.842 --> 00:14:19.260 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:14:19.260 --> 00:14:21.360 align:middle line:84%
Welcome to the IU
libraries, everyone.

00:14:21.360 --> 00:14:24.690 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:14:24.690 --> 00:14:28.110 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: But there
has been, historically,

00:14:28.110 --> 00:14:31.110 align:middle line:84%
a lot of, I wouldn't
say tension,

00:14:31.110 --> 00:14:34.470 align:middle line:84%
but difference among the
librarians and archivists.

00:14:34.470 --> 00:14:36.000 align:middle line:90%
It's the same business, please.

00:14:36.000 --> 00:14:37.110 align:middle line:90%
It's the same business.

00:14:37.110 --> 00:14:39.843 align:middle line:84%
Collect, protect, encourage
the use of, fill in the blank.

00:14:39.843 --> 00:14:40.635 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah.

00:14:40.635 --> 00:14:43.680 align:middle line:90%


00:14:43.680 --> 00:14:45.570 align:middle line:84%
So you were nominated
for the position

00:14:45.570 --> 00:14:46.950 align:middle line:90%
by President Barack Obama.

00:14:46.950 --> 00:14:47.950 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Exactly.

00:14:47.950 --> 00:14:50.110 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: But you served
under President Obama,

00:14:50.110 --> 00:14:52.500 align:middle line:84%
President Trump, and
then President Biden.

00:14:52.500 --> 00:14:53.490 align:middle line:90%
So you've kind of--

00:14:53.490 --> 00:14:55.323 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: It's a
lifetime appointment.

00:14:55.323 --> 00:14:57.640 align:middle line:84%
There is no term for the
archivists in the United

00:14:57.640 --> 00:14:59.130 align:middle line:90%
States.

00:14:59.130 --> 00:15:02.310 align:middle line:84%
So at the end of
an administration

00:15:02.310 --> 00:15:05.400 align:middle line:84%
there are 4,000
presidential appointments.

00:15:05.400 --> 00:15:06.870 align:middle line:84%
And at the end of
an administration

00:15:06.870 --> 00:15:08.400 align:middle line:90%
4,000 people leave.

00:15:08.400 --> 00:15:12.900 align:middle line:84%
And so if you have a
presidential appointment,

00:15:12.900 --> 00:15:15.210 align:middle line:84%
you get a notice from
the incoming president

00:15:15.210 --> 00:15:18.160 align:middle line:84%
asking you to submit
your resignation,

00:15:18.160 --> 00:15:20.460 align:middle line:84%
except the archivist
doesn't get that notice.

00:15:20.460 --> 00:15:22.210 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Oh, well,
that's a job perk.

00:15:22.210 --> 00:15:23.127 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Right.

00:15:23.127 --> 00:15:24.280 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah.

00:15:24.280 --> 00:15:26.530 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: So one
of the huge challenges

00:15:26.530 --> 00:15:28.270 align:middle line:84%
for the National
Archives is to ensure

00:15:28.270 --> 00:15:30.760 align:middle line:84%
that those 4,000
people who are leaving

00:15:30.760 --> 00:15:33.100 align:middle line:84%
are leaving their
records behind.

00:15:33.100 --> 00:15:34.030 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Right.

00:15:34.030 --> 00:15:35.740 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: And
more challenging

00:15:35.740 --> 00:15:38.680 align:middle line:84%
is to ensure that those
4,000 people coming in

00:15:38.680 --> 00:15:39.947 align:middle line:90%
know what the rules are.

00:15:39.947 --> 00:15:40.780 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Right.

00:15:40.780 --> 00:15:41.470 align:middle line:90%
Yeah.

00:15:41.470 --> 00:15:44.740 align:middle line:84%
So you kind of touched
on this a little bit,

00:15:44.740 --> 00:15:48.385 align:middle line:90%
but you were nominated in--

00:15:48.385 --> 00:15:53.110 align:middle line:84%
I think it was July
of 2009, correct?

00:15:53.110 --> 00:15:57.460 align:middle line:84%
And you were confirmed-- so
all presidential appointments

00:15:57.460 --> 00:16:00.850 align:middle line:84%
have to be vetted by the
United States Senate.

00:16:00.850 --> 00:16:03.220 align:middle line:90%
There are confirmation hearings.

00:16:03.220 --> 00:16:06.730 align:middle line:84%
Some of you might have
watched them on CNN or c-span.

00:16:06.730 --> 00:16:11.353 align:middle line:84%
So everyone has to go
through the whole grilling

00:16:11.353 --> 00:16:12.520 align:middle line:90%
process of having a hearing.

00:16:12.520 --> 00:16:13.770 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Very Invasive.

00:16:13.770 --> 00:16:16.630 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Right, and
so you were actually--

00:16:16.630 --> 00:16:21.040 align:middle line:84%
I think that you were
nominated in July of 2009

00:16:21.040 --> 00:16:22.570 align:middle line:90%
and then confirmed in November.

00:16:22.570 --> 00:16:23.020 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: November

00:16:23.020 --> 00:16:24.940 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: So essentially
three months later.

00:16:24.940 --> 00:16:25.720 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Right

00:16:25.720 --> 00:16:28.053 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: The current
Archivist of the United States

00:16:28.053 --> 00:16:31.450 align:middle line:84%
was nominated in, I
think, August of 2022

00:16:31.450 --> 00:16:34.960 align:middle line:84%
and wasn't confirmed
until May of 2023.

00:16:34.960 --> 00:16:39.280 align:middle line:84%
So it took nine months
to get her confirmed.

00:16:39.280 --> 00:16:41.950 align:middle line:90%
So what is that process like?

00:16:41.950 --> 00:16:45.910 align:middle line:84%
What is it like to be nominated
and go through that kind of--

00:16:45.910 --> 00:16:47.950 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: As I
said, it's very invasive.

00:16:47.950 --> 00:16:52.180 align:middle line:90%


00:16:52.180 --> 00:16:54.800 align:middle line:84%
So when Tom left
my office, he said,

00:16:54.800 --> 00:16:56.860 align:middle line:84%
would you come to Washington
and talk some more?

00:16:56.860 --> 00:16:59.830 align:middle line:84%
And that's when I met
with the full committee

00:16:59.830 --> 00:17:02.360 align:middle line:84%
at the White House and
talked about the job.

00:17:02.360 --> 00:17:06.369 align:middle line:84%
And as I was leaving
the room, David Jacobson

00:17:06.369 --> 00:17:08.780 align:middle line:90%
who was the head of that--

00:17:08.780 --> 00:17:12.579 align:middle line:84%
Who was Kyle's boss said, so can
we consider you our candidate.

00:17:12.579 --> 00:17:13.540 align:middle line:90%
And I said, yes.

00:17:13.540 --> 00:17:15.670 align:middle line:84%
And at that point
it was locked down.

00:17:15.670 --> 00:17:17.740 align:middle line:84%
I couldn't talk to
anyone except my wife

00:17:17.740 --> 00:17:19.390 align:middle line:90%
about what was going on.

00:17:19.390 --> 00:17:23.230 align:middle line:84%
And that launched an
investigative process.

00:17:23.230 --> 00:17:26.470 align:middle line:84%
FBI agents spread out
across the country talking

00:17:26.470 --> 00:17:29.470 align:middle line:90%
to anyone I ever had known.

00:17:29.470 --> 00:17:35.540 align:middle line:84%
And I kept getting these emails
from folks, friends saying,

00:17:35.540 --> 00:17:37.780 align:middle line:90%
what the hell is going on?

00:17:37.780 --> 00:17:39.640 align:middle line:90%
The FBI is at my door.

00:17:39.640 --> 00:17:40.810 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Oh no.

00:17:40.810 --> 00:17:42.370 align:middle line:84%
That is not what
you want to hear.

00:17:42.370 --> 00:17:43.745 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO:
All they can tell

00:17:43.745 --> 00:17:45.742 align:middle line:84%
me is that it's not a
criminal investigation.

00:17:45.742 --> 00:17:46.450 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Oh.

00:17:46.450 --> 00:17:48.010 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:17:48.010 --> 00:17:49.360 align:middle line:90%
Thanks, yeah.

00:17:49.360 --> 00:17:52.600 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: So I
passed those tests.

00:17:52.600 --> 00:17:57.310 align:middle line:84%
And then the next
phase is you have

00:17:57.310 --> 00:18:00.550 align:middle line:84%
to meet with every member
of the Senate Committee

00:18:00.550 --> 00:18:01.690 align:middle line:90%
that's voting on you.

00:18:01.690 --> 00:18:07.430 align:middle line:84%
So a White House
shepherd and I visited

00:18:07.430 --> 00:18:09.050 align:middle line:90%
each member of the committee.

00:18:09.050 --> 00:18:13.940 align:middle line:84%
And my favorite visit was
with an unnamed Senator who

00:18:13.940 --> 00:18:15.257 align:middle line:90%
asked me the killer question.

00:18:15.257 --> 00:18:16.340 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Which state?

00:18:16.340 --> 00:18:17.990 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: I'm not even
going to mention the state.

00:18:17.990 --> 00:18:18.375 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: I'm just kidding.

00:18:18.375 --> 00:18:18.760 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHS]

00:18:18.760 --> 00:18:20.843 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: They asked
me the killer question,

00:18:20.843 --> 00:18:23.790 align:middle line:84%
so why is it that you want to
be the architect of the United

00:18:23.790 --> 00:18:24.290 align:middle line:90%
States?

00:18:24.290 --> 00:18:24.998 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Oh.

00:18:24.998 --> 00:18:27.380 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:18:27.380 --> 00:18:28.280 align:middle line:90%
Yeah.

00:18:28.280 --> 00:18:32.508 align:middle line:84%
And you said, because I
like domes and columns.

00:18:32.508 --> 00:18:34.550 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: No, I
pretended he said archivist

00:18:34.550 --> 00:18:38.650 align:middle line:84%
and I talked about his
records, his papers.

00:18:38.650 --> 00:18:41.910 align:middle line:84%
And as we were leaving, the
shepherd turned to me and said,

00:18:41.910 --> 00:18:43.250 align:middle line:90%
did he say architect?

00:18:43.250 --> 00:18:44.450 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:18:44.450 --> 00:18:47.088 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Because there is
an archivist-- or architect.

00:18:47.088 --> 00:18:48.380 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Of the Capitol.

00:18:48.380 --> 00:18:49.588 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Of the Capitol.

00:18:49.588 --> 00:18:50.210 align:middle line:90%
Right, so.

00:18:50.210 --> 00:18:51.770 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: Not architect
of the United States.

00:18:51.770 --> 00:18:52.070 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: No,no,no.

00:18:52.070 --> 00:18:53.760 align:middle line:84%
No architect of
the United States.

00:18:53.760 --> 00:18:56.180 align:middle line:90%
So.

00:18:56.180 --> 00:18:58.670 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: So
then as a hearing.

00:18:58.670 --> 00:19:03.830 align:middle line:84%
And I think I'm
the last person who

00:19:03.830 --> 00:19:06.708 align:middle line:84%
had a swift appointment and
then a vote by the full Senate.

00:19:06.708 --> 00:19:07.500 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah.

00:19:07.500 --> 00:19:08.292 align:middle line:90%
You know, because--

00:19:08.292 --> 00:19:12.360 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: But as
you've seen recently,

00:19:12.360 --> 00:19:15.750 align:middle line:84%
any member of the Senate could
put a hold on a nomination.

00:19:15.750 --> 00:19:16.500 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah

00:19:16.500 --> 00:19:18.840 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: And Lamar
Alexander of Tennessee

00:19:18.840 --> 00:19:20.245 align:middle line:90%
put a hold on my nomination.

00:19:20.245 --> 00:19:21.120 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Really?

00:19:21.120 --> 00:19:22.020 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Yeah.

00:19:22.020 --> 00:19:24.015 align:middle line:84%
The White House
couldn't figure out--

00:19:24.015 --> 00:19:25.890 align:middle line:84%
nobody could figure out
what the problem was.

00:19:25.890 --> 00:19:30.270 align:middle line:84%
So they sent me to meet with
Lamar, who was very embarrassed

00:19:30.270 --> 00:19:32.100 align:middle line:90%
that he had put a hold on it.

00:19:32.100 --> 00:19:35.610 align:middle line:84%
But it turns out that
one of his constituents

00:19:35.610 --> 00:19:39.180 align:middle line:84%
reported that the director
of the Nixon Library

00:19:39.180 --> 00:19:41.970 align:middle line:84%
was saying some pretty
anti-Nixon things,

00:19:41.970 --> 00:19:45.490 align:middle line:84%
and he thought I
should know about that.

00:19:45.490 --> 00:19:47.010 align:middle line:84%
And once he got
that off the table,

00:19:47.010 --> 00:19:49.680 align:middle line:84%
then we had a wonderful
conversation about his--

00:19:49.680 --> 00:19:53.940 align:middle line:84%
he used to be a president of
the University of Tennessee.

00:19:53.940 --> 00:19:57.180 align:middle line:84%
So we talked about
higher education.

00:19:57.180 --> 00:19:59.640 align:middle line:84%
He really embarrassed
because his wife, Honey,

00:19:59.640 --> 00:20:01.850 align:middle line:84%
was on the National
Archives Foundation board.

00:20:01.850 --> 00:20:02.850 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Ooh-ho-ho.

00:20:02.850 --> 00:20:05.010 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:20:05.010 --> 00:20:07.050 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: So she
wasn't happy about him

00:20:07.050 --> 00:20:08.020 align:middle line:90%
putting a hold on it.

00:20:08.020 --> 00:20:11.860 align:middle line:84%
So as soon as I left the
office, they lifted the hold.

00:20:11.860 --> 00:20:18.748 align:middle line:84%
And I think it was the last
unanimous vote on a nomination.

00:20:18.748 --> 00:20:19.540 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah.

00:20:19.540 --> 00:20:20.410 align:middle line:90%
Well, yeah.

00:20:20.410 --> 00:20:23.470 align:middle line:84%
Because, like I said, the
current Archivist of the United

00:20:23.470 --> 00:20:25.000 align:middle line:90%
States, it was very con--

00:20:25.000 --> 00:20:28.190 align:middle line:90%
Not, I think, because of her.

00:20:28.190 --> 00:20:28.690 align:middle line:90%
But--

00:20:28.690 --> 00:20:30.880 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: No,
it's the dysfunction

00:20:30.880 --> 00:20:36.130 align:middle line:84%
of the Hill in terms of
the non-partisan approach

00:20:36.130 --> 00:20:36.970 align:middle line:90%
to everything.

00:20:36.970 --> 00:20:38.380 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Right.

00:20:38.380 --> 00:20:42.220 align:middle line:90%
So just to clarify for everyone.

00:20:42.220 --> 00:20:45.460 align:middle line:84%
So you essentially
are the director

00:20:45.460 --> 00:20:47.440 align:middle line:84%
and the head of the
National Archives, right.

00:20:47.440 --> 00:20:49.480 align:middle line:84%
Technically the National
Archives and Records

00:20:49.480 --> 00:20:50.890 align:middle line:90%
Administration.

00:20:50.890 --> 00:20:53.960 align:middle line:84%
And I kind of, and
correct me if I'm wrong,

00:20:53.960 --> 00:20:56.560 align:middle line:84%
but I think part
of the reason why

00:20:56.560 --> 00:21:01.060 align:middle line:84%
there is such an invasive
process for vetting

00:21:01.060 --> 00:21:04.030 align:middle line:84%
the potential Archivist
of the United States,

00:21:04.030 --> 00:21:09.400 align:middle line:84%
and sending the FBI, and finding
out everything from everyone

00:21:09.400 --> 00:21:14.440 align:middle line:84%
who ever knew you is because
you have access to some really

00:21:14.440 --> 00:21:17.200 align:middle line:90%
important documents.

00:21:17.200 --> 00:21:17.867 align:middle line:90%
No is this not--

00:21:17.867 --> 00:21:19.492 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: The
process is the same

00:21:19.492 --> 00:21:20.867 align:middle line:84%
for any presidential
appointment.

00:21:20.867 --> 00:21:21.825 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Oh, Yeah.

00:21:21.825 --> 00:21:22.720 align:middle line:90%
Well no, I know that.

00:21:22.720 --> 00:21:25.420 align:middle line:84%
But I guess it's
this idea that they

00:21:25.420 --> 00:21:28.090 align:middle line:84%
don't want anyone, any
presidential appointment,

00:21:28.090 --> 00:21:29.810 align:middle line:84%
to be in a position
to be blackmailed--

00:21:29.810 --> 00:21:31.060 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Oh yeah, sure.

00:21:31.060 --> 00:21:32.977 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: --or to
have something over you,

00:21:32.977 --> 00:21:37.840 align:middle line:84%
or be able to leak documents,
or do anything like this.

00:21:37.840 --> 00:21:40.580 align:middle line:84%
And in your case, with
the National Archives,

00:21:40.580 --> 00:21:42.940 align:middle line:84%
this is the home of
all of the founding

00:21:42.940 --> 00:21:45.220 align:middle line:90%
documents of this country.

00:21:45.220 --> 00:21:47.350 align:middle line:84%
The Declaration of
Independence is there.

00:21:47.350 --> 00:21:48.910 align:middle line:90%
The US Constitution.

00:21:48.910 --> 00:21:51.220 align:middle line:90%
The Bill of Rights.

00:21:51.220 --> 00:21:53.320 align:middle line:90%
And they're on display.

00:21:53.320 --> 00:21:56.650 align:middle line:84%
They're just in this
wonderful display area.

00:21:56.650 --> 00:21:58.430 align:middle line:84%
When I visited
several years ago,

00:21:58.430 --> 00:22:01.240 align:middle line:90%
there were a lot of school kids.

00:22:01.240 --> 00:22:05.350 align:middle line:84%
It was a very popular
school kid destination.

00:22:05.350 --> 00:22:09.513 align:middle line:84%
I actually read that you
wanted to do sleepovers.

00:22:09.513 --> 00:22:10.930 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO:
We did sleepovers.

00:22:10.930 --> 00:22:13.030 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Did you do
sleepovers in the rotunda?

00:22:13.030 --> 00:22:15.572 align:middle line:84%
Was it just for school kids, or
were adults part of this too?

00:22:15.572 --> 00:22:17.410 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO:
Twice a year we did,

00:22:17.410 --> 00:22:18.712 align:middle line:90%
for kids 8 to 12 years old.

00:22:18.712 --> 00:22:19.420 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: OK.

00:22:19.420 --> 00:22:22.000 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: They had
to come with an adult.

00:22:22.000 --> 00:22:27.490 align:middle line:84%
And we were limited
to, I think, 80 people.

00:22:27.490 --> 00:22:31.420 align:middle line:84%
We started on a
Saturday night evening.

00:22:31.420 --> 00:22:34.600 align:middle line:84%
We had a whole evening full
of activities for them,

00:22:34.600 --> 00:22:39.378 align:middle line:84%
scavenger hunts, and
movies, and snacks, and--

00:22:39.378 --> 00:22:41.920 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Not peanut butter
and jelly sandwiches, though.

00:22:41.920 --> 00:22:43.150 align:middle line:90%
Near the--

00:22:43.150 --> 00:22:46.270 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: Yeah, we
had a special area for food.

00:22:46.270 --> 00:22:47.680 align:middle line:90%
Not in the rotunda--

00:22:47.680 --> 00:22:48.850 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Not with
the Declaration of--

00:22:48.850 --> 00:22:49.350 align:middle line:90%
OK.

00:22:49.350 --> 00:22:50.200 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: No.

00:22:50.200 --> 00:22:53.800 align:middle line:84%
And they brought sleeping
bags and stuff to sleep.

00:22:53.800 --> 00:22:59.240 align:middle line:90%
And lights out at 11 o'clock.

00:22:59.240 --> 00:23:02.000 align:middle line:84%
And they slept on the
floor of the rotunda

00:23:02.000 --> 00:23:04.010 align:middle line:90%
in the presence of the charters.

00:23:04.010 --> 00:23:05.504 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Wow.

00:23:05.504 --> 00:23:08.010 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: And
on Sunday morning,

00:23:08.010 --> 00:23:09.710 align:middle line:90%
we did a pancake breakfast.

00:23:09.710 --> 00:23:10.832 align:middle line:90%
I flipped pancakes.

00:23:10.832 --> 00:23:11.540 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Oh.

00:23:11.540 --> 00:23:12.230 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHS]

00:23:12.230 --> 00:23:13.730 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: Yeah,
it was a lot of fun.

00:23:13.730 --> 00:23:14.938 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Oh, that's so--

00:23:14.938 --> 00:23:17.450 align:middle line:84%
And the way I
understand it is, that

00:23:17.450 --> 00:23:22.070 align:middle line:84%
was part of a very important
initiative to you, which

00:23:22.070 --> 00:23:26.810 align:middle line:84%
was to make the collections
of the National Archives

00:23:26.810 --> 00:23:28.010 align:middle line:90%
accessible to people.

00:23:28.010 --> 00:23:32.120 align:middle line:84%
And invite the public in
and kind of break down

00:23:32.120 --> 00:23:33.905 align:middle line:90%
that barrier.

00:23:33.905 --> 00:23:35.030 align:middle line:90%
So was that a part of that?

00:23:35.030 --> 00:23:37.460 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: It was a
piece of the open government

00:23:37.460 --> 00:23:41.770 align:middle line:84%
initiative where we
were trying to make

00:23:41.770 --> 00:23:44.730 align:middle line:84%
each agency more
user responsive,

00:23:44.730 --> 00:23:47.366 align:middle line:90%
more reflective of the--

00:23:47.366 --> 00:23:50.108 align:middle line:90%
to break down those walls.

00:23:50.108 --> 00:23:50.900 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah.

00:23:50.900 --> 00:23:55.770 align:middle line:84%
And so the National
Archives, like I said,

00:23:55.770 --> 00:23:58.200 align:middle line:84%
has these founding documents
of the country in it.

00:23:58.200 --> 00:24:01.110 align:middle line:84%
And it has things like the
Emancipation Proclamation

00:24:01.110 --> 00:24:04.083 align:middle line:84%
and the Treaty of the
Louisiana Purchase.

00:24:04.083 --> 00:24:05.250 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: My favorite.

00:24:05.250 --> 00:24:09.600 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah,
but there's also over--

00:24:09.600 --> 00:24:14.550 align:middle line:84%
approximately-- 13 billion other
analog materials, photographs,

00:24:14.550 --> 00:24:15.840 align:middle line:90%
documents, maps.

00:24:15.840 --> 00:24:17.170 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: No that
doesn't include photographs.

00:24:17.170 --> 00:24:18.545 align:middle line:84%
There are 43
million photographs.

00:24:18.545 --> 00:24:20.470 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: 43,
well, 43 million.

00:24:20.470 --> 00:24:21.450 align:middle line:90%
I did the math.

00:24:21.450 --> 00:24:22.470 align:middle line:90%
That's 13.8 billion.

00:24:22.470 --> 00:24:23.800 align:middle line:90%
Oh, 43 million photographs?

00:24:23.800 --> 00:24:26.050 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: I used to
scare the staff when I said,

00:24:26.050 --> 00:24:27.450 align:middle line:90%
we should be doing an inventory.

00:24:27.450 --> 00:24:28.242 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah.

00:24:28.242 --> 00:24:32.370 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:24:32.370 --> 00:24:33.990 align:middle line:90%
I will try to ignore that.

00:24:33.990 --> 00:24:35.320 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:24:35.320 --> 00:24:40.440 align:middle line:84%
And then over 33 billion
electronic records

00:24:40.440 --> 00:24:41.340 align:middle line:90%
and counting.

00:24:41.340 --> 00:24:42.423 align:middle line:90%
I assume, right?

00:24:42.423 --> 00:24:44.340 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: Where
did you get that figure?

00:24:44.340 --> 00:24:45.810 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Off
of your website.

00:24:45.810 --> 00:24:47.102 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Not 33 billion.

00:24:47.102 --> 00:24:48.668 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: 33
billion with a b.

00:24:48.668 --> 00:24:49.460 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: No.

00:24:49.460 --> 00:24:49.890 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Billion.

00:24:49.890 --> 00:24:50.610 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: No.

00:24:50.610 --> 00:24:51.270 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Oh.

00:24:51.270 --> 00:24:53.040 align:middle line:84%
Well then the website
needs to be updated.

00:24:53.040 --> 00:24:53.910 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: I
guess it's wrong.

00:24:53.910 --> 00:24:54.702 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah.

00:24:54.702 --> 00:24:57.522 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: It's like six
billion electronic records.

00:24:57.522 --> 00:24:58.230 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Oh.

00:24:58.230 --> 00:25:00.018 align:middle line:90%
Well, the website is wrong.

00:25:00.018 --> 00:25:00.810 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: OK.

00:25:00.810 --> 00:25:01.602 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah.

00:25:01.602 --> 00:25:02.185 align:middle line:90%
So.

00:25:02.185 --> 00:25:03.810 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: Not
my problem anymore.

00:25:03.810 --> 00:25:05.018 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Right, exactly.

00:25:05.018 --> 00:25:07.380 align:middle line:90%
Not your problem anymore.

00:25:07.380 --> 00:25:08.493 align:middle line:90%
So what else?

00:25:08.493 --> 00:25:10.410 align:middle line:84%
I mean, what are some
of your favorite things.

00:25:10.410 --> 00:25:12.600 align:middle line:84%
Like, what other
collections are there

00:25:12.600 --> 00:25:17.100 align:middle line:84%
besides federal records,
and Presidential Records,

00:25:17.100 --> 00:25:19.102 align:middle line:84%
and official records,
but what else is there?

00:25:19.102 --> 00:25:20.560 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: A
couple of things.

00:25:20.560 --> 00:25:25.560 align:middle line:84%
One of one of my favorite
parts of the collection

00:25:25.560 --> 00:25:30.510 align:middle line:84%
are the treaties that we
signed with Native nations.

00:25:30.510 --> 00:25:35.550 align:middle line:84%
So there are 375 of them which
have been digitized and are now

00:25:35.550 --> 00:25:39.030 align:middle line:90%
up and available on our website.

00:25:39.030 --> 00:25:44.310 align:middle line:84%
They're the saddest documents,
I think, in our collection.

00:25:44.310 --> 00:25:46.140 align:middle line:84%
Because they spell
out everything

00:25:46.140 --> 00:25:48.540 align:middle line:84%
that we promised to the
Indians while we grabbed

00:25:48.540 --> 00:25:49.830 align:middle line:90%
their land and their water.

00:25:49.830 --> 00:25:56.850 align:middle line:84%
And visited frequently by
tribal elders and tribal lawyers

00:25:56.850 --> 00:26:02.400 align:middle line:84%
who are working on federal cases
on land reuse and water rights.

00:26:02.400 --> 00:26:05.430 align:middle line:84%
So that's one piece
of the collection.

00:26:05.430 --> 00:26:09.740 align:middle line:84%
But there's another
piece too that I would

00:26:09.740 --> 00:26:11.510 align:middle line:90%
put in the favorite category.

00:26:11.510 --> 00:26:13.670 align:middle line:84%
When I became the
archivist and met

00:26:13.670 --> 00:26:16.475 align:middle line:84%
with the directors of the
Presidential Libraries

00:26:16.475 --> 00:26:18.350 align:middle line:84%
for the first time, they
went around the room

00:26:18.350 --> 00:26:19.700 align:middle line:90%
and introduced themselves.

00:26:19.700 --> 00:26:21.920 align:middle line:84%
And the director of
the Kennedy handed me

00:26:21.920 --> 00:26:24.500 align:middle line:84%
a copy of a letter that a
kid wrote to the president,

00:26:24.500 --> 00:26:29.090 align:middle line:84%
asking for information about
the proposed Peace Corps.

00:26:29.090 --> 00:26:30.410 align:middle line:90%
It's a letter from me.

00:26:30.410 --> 00:26:31.100 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:26:31.100 --> 00:26:32.022 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah.

00:26:32.022 --> 00:26:33.980 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: Two weeks
later, the Eisenhower

00:26:33.980 --> 00:26:35.980 align:middle line:84%
called to say they had
found two letters from me

00:26:35.980 --> 00:26:37.250 align:middle line:90%
to President Eisenhower.

00:26:37.250 --> 00:26:39.650 align:middle line:84%
And when I was at the
LBJ, they handed me

00:26:39.650 --> 00:26:43.280 align:middle line:84%
a copy of the letter that I
sent to LBJ, congratulating him

00:26:43.280 --> 00:26:44.960 align:middle line:84%
for signing the
Civil Rights Act.

00:26:44.960 --> 00:26:45.830 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah.

00:26:45.830 --> 00:26:47.090 align:middle line:90%
This actually--

00:26:47.090 --> 00:26:48.620 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO:
Those are records,

00:26:48.620 --> 00:26:50.480 align:middle line:90%
presidential correspondence.

00:26:50.480 --> 00:26:53.630 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Actually,
so recently, I

00:26:53.630 --> 00:26:57.230 align:middle line:84%
received an email from
somebody you have met before.

00:26:57.230 --> 00:26:59.480 align:middle line:84%
He's an educator who
lives in North Carolina.

00:26:59.480 --> 00:27:04.600 align:middle line:84%
And his advice to me was,
when you talk to David,

00:27:04.600 --> 00:27:06.930 align:middle line:84%
you might ask him about
some of the artifacts he

00:27:06.930 --> 00:27:09.480 align:middle line:84%
had in his office,
including a letter

00:27:09.480 --> 00:27:11.115 align:middle line:90%
he wrote to LBJ and perhaps--

00:27:11.115 --> 00:27:12.240 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Facsimiles.

00:27:12.240 --> 00:27:13.698 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI:
Facsimiles, for sure.

00:27:13.698 --> 00:27:15.480 align:middle line:90%
For sure.

00:27:15.480 --> 00:27:17.130 align:middle line:90%
But I thought this was a great--

00:27:17.130 --> 00:27:19.080 align:middle line:84%
that these letters
were from you.

00:27:19.080 --> 00:27:21.180 align:middle line:84%
And you found them
in the archives,

00:27:21.180 --> 00:27:24.660 align:middle line:84%
which struck me
because, essentially,

00:27:24.660 --> 00:27:28.740 align:middle line:84%
we, as citizens,
are in the archives.

00:27:28.740 --> 00:27:31.620 align:middle line:84%
It is not just for
Presidential Records

00:27:31.620 --> 00:27:34.290 align:middle line:90%
and of course, it is for that.

00:27:34.290 --> 00:27:36.780 align:middle line:84%
But we're all in
it, essentially.

00:27:36.780 --> 00:27:39.492 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: One of the
activities for the sleepover

00:27:39.492 --> 00:27:40.950 align:middle line:84%
is kids get an
opportunity to write

00:27:40.950 --> 00:27:42.360 align:middle line:90%
a letter to the president.

00:27:42.360 --> 00:27:43.380 align:middle line:90%
And we deliver them.

00:27:43.380 --> 00:27:45.588 align:middle line:84%
On Monday morning we deliver
them to the White House,

00:27:45.588 --> 00:27:48.390 align:middle line:90%
and President Obama responded.

00:27:48.390 --> 00:27:50.110 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Awe.

00:27:50.110 --> 00:27:53.520 align:middle line:84%
That reminds me
actually of, in 2018,

00:27:53.520 --> 00:27:55.710 align:middle line:84%
when I had an
opportunity to visit

00:27:55.710 --> 00:28:00.860 align:middle line:84%
Richard Lugar at
his office, and I

00:28:00.860 --> 00:28:02.240 align:middle line:90%
had my picture taken with him.

00:28:02.240 --> 00:28:05.450 align:middle line:84%
And in the mail I
got a signed copy.

00:28:05.450 --> 00:28:08.150 align:middle line:84%
And I said, do I
have to archive this?

00:28:08.150 --> 00:28:09.305 align:middle line:90%
Like, I have this picture.

00:28:09.305 --> 00:28:10.400 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: [LAUGHS]

00:28:10.400 --> 00:28:13.790 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: But
I've also read things,

00:28:13.790 --> 00:28:17.000 align:middle line:84%
where for instance, the
National Archives has veterans

00:28:17.000 --> 00:28:19.430 align:middle line:90%
records and military records.

00:28:19.430 --> 00:28:23.090 align:middle line:84%
And you, yourself,
are a veteran, right.

00:28:23.090 --> 00:28:27.110 align:middle line:84%
And there were several blog
posts about the 1950 census

00:28:27.110 --> 00:28:30.350 align:middle line:84%
which was recently
released, and people

00:28:30.350 --> 00:28:33.320 align:middle line:84%
who found their relatives
online, or found

00:28:33.320 --> 00:28:36.260 align:middle line:90%
their parents in the census.

00:28:36.260 --> 00:28:40.430 align:middle line:84%
So essentially, again, we're
all in the National Archives.

00:28:40.430 --> 00:28:41.900 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Exactly.

00:28:41.900 --> 00:28:45.200 align:middle line:84%
So when I visited Saint Louis,
where our military records are,

00:28:45.200 --> 00:28:49.820 align:middle line:84%
there's a special vault
for high-end veterans.

00:28:49.820 --> 00:28:53.930 align:middle line:84%
Records that we want make
sure we want to make sure

00:28:53.930 --> 00:28:59.520 align:middle line:90%
aren't tampered or messed up.

00:28:59.520 --> 00:29:01.360 align:middle line:84%
Not that there's a
lot of that goes on.

00:29:01.360 --> 00:29:03.940 align:middle line:90%
But the VIP vaults.

00:29:03.940 --> 00:29:06.360 align:middle line:84%
So they took me on a
tour of the VIP vault

00:29:06.360 --> 00:29:09.222 align:middle line:84%
and handed me Elvis's
service record.

00:29:09.222 --> 00:29:09.930 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Oh.

00:29:09.930 --> 00:29:12.270 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:29:12.270 --> 00:29:13.770 align:middle line:90%
And was it?

00:29:13.770 --> 00:29:17.502 align:middle line:84%
Oh Yeah, so I think
that recently--

00:29:17.502 --> 00:29:19.210 align:middle line:84%
and I want to see if
this is still true--

00:29:19.210 --> 00:29:22.980 align:middle line:84%
but recently we watched a
program from the New York

00:29:22.980 --> 00:29:24.690 align:middle line:84%
Historical Society
that was an interview

00:29:24.690 --> 00:29:27.030 align:middle line:84%
with the current Archivist
of the United States, Colleen

00:29:27.030 --> 00:29:27.570 align:middle line:90%
Shogan.

00:29:27.570 --> 00:29:29.280 align:middle line:84%
And she was asked
the question of what

00:29:29.280 --> 00:29:33.000 align:middle line:84%
is the most requested
and popular item.

00:29:33.000 --> 00:29:35.340 align:middle line:84%
And she said it was
the photograph of Elvis

00:29:35.340 --> 00:29:36.667 align:middle line:90%
with President Richard Nixon.

00:29:36.667 --> 00:29:37.500 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Yes.

00:29:37.500 --> 00:29:38.040 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Is that?

00:29:38.040 --> 00:29:39.060 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO:
It's a great story.

00:29:39.060 --> 00:29:39.480 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah?

00:29:39.480 --> 00:29:40.210 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: You
want to hear it?

00:29:40.210 --> 00:29:40.830 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Absolutely.

00:29:40.830 --> 00:29:41.380 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: OK.

00:29:41.380 --> 00:29:42.922 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Do
you want to hear it?

00:29:42.922 --> 00:29:44.220 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:29:44.220 --> 00:29:49.380 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: So
Elvis collected badges.

00:29:49.380 --> 00:29:53.400 align:middle line:84%
And he had badges from
all over the country.

00:29:53.400 --> 00:29:57.570 align:middle line:84%
And the one that he really
wanted was an FBI badge,

00:29:57.570 --> 00:30:00.300 align:middle line:84%
and the FBI refused
to give him a badge.

00:30:00.300 --> 00:30:08.370 align:middle line:84%
So he took it upon himself
to fly from Los Angeles--

00:30:08.370 --> 00:30:09.480 align:middle line:90%
he was on the West Coast.

00:30:09.480 --> 00:30:13.710 align:middle line:84%
He flew to Washington
on American Airlines

00:30:13.710 --> 00:30:17.700 align:middle line:84%
because he asked the flight
attendant for stationery

00:30:17.700 --> 00:30:22.980 align:middle line:84%
to write a letter
to President Nixon,

00:30:22.980 --> 00:30:26.580 align:middle line:84%
asking to meet with him
because he wanted to volunteer

00:30:26.580 --> 00:30:28.440 align:middle line:90%
for his war on drugs.

00:30:28.440 --> 00:30:30.030 align:middle line:90%
Nothing about badges.

00:30:30.030 --> 00:30:31.350 align:middle line:90%
Nothing about badges.

00:30:31.350 --> 00:30:32.250 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Oh.

00:30:32.250 --> 00:30:35.850 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: And he and he
got into a cab at the airport

00:30:35.850 --> 00:30:39.480 align:middle line:84%
and got delivered
to the West Wing

00:30:39.480 --> 00:30:43.005 align:middle line:84%
gate, where he handed the
letter in, which you can't do.

00:30:43.005 --> 00:30:44.130 align:middle line:90%
They won't accept anything.

00:30:44.130 --> 00:30:48.180 align:middle line:84%
So don't try and leave a letter
at the gate at the White House.

00:30:48.180 --> 00:30:50.910 align:middle line:90%
And it ended up in Bud Krogh--

00:30:50.910 --> 00:30:53.220 align:middle line:84%
Bud Krogh, who
was chief of Staff

00:30:53.220 --> 00:30:56.940 align:middle line:84%
to President Nixon
and a huge Elvis fan.

00:30:56.940 --> 00:30:59.070 align:middle line:90%
It ended up in his hands.

00:30:59.070 --> 00:31:04.760 align:middle line:84%
And sure enough, Elvis was
invited, that afternoon,

00:31:04.760 --> 00:31:08.570 align:middle line:84%
to come and to visit
with the president.

00:31:08.570 --> 00:31:12.150 align:middle line:90%


00:31:12.150 --> 00:31:13.470 align:middle line:90%
Bud did a program with us.

00:31:13.470 --> 00:31:17.280 align:middle line:84%
And if you google Bud Krogh
Elvis National Archives,

00:31:17.280 --> 00:31:19.650 align:middle line:84%
you can watch this
wonderful conversation

00:31:19.650 --> 00:31:21.840 align:middle line:84%
with Bud telling
the story of Nixon

00:31:21.840 --> 00:31:23.550 align:middle line:84%
not really knowing
who Elvis was.

00:31:23.550 --> 00:31:26.670 align:middle line:84%
And do I really have
to meet with him?

00:31:26.670 --> 00:31:28.500 align:middle line:90%
And all of this.

00:31:28.500 --> 00:31:31.590 align:middle line:90%


00:31:31.590 --> 00:31:34.410 align:middle line:84%
There wasn't any conversation
about drugs or anything

00:31:34.410 --> 00:31:38.070 align:middle line:84%
in this one on one
with the president,

00:31:38.070 --> 00:31:40.920 align:middle line:84%
but he got to the point
where he wanted a badge.

00:31:40.920 --> 00:31:43.830 align:middle line:84%
He really wanted an FBI badge,
so he asked Nixon for it.

00:31:43.830 --> 00:31:46.620 align:middle line:84%
And Nixon turned to Bud
and said, can I do that?

00:31:46.620 --> 00:31:48.810 align:middle line:84%
And Bud Krogh says,
of course you can.

00:31:48.810 --> 00:31:49.710 align:middle line:90%
You're the president.

00:31:49.710 --> 00:31:50.725 align:middle line:90%
So guess what?

00:31:50.725 --> 00:31:52.350 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Did he
get the FBI badge?

00:31:52.350 --> 00:31:53.910 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: He
got the FBI badge.

00:31:53.910 --> 00:31:56.340 align:middle line:84%
And then Bud tells
the story of--

00:31:56.340 --> 00:31:58.380 align:middle line:90%
this is true of every president.

00:31:58.380 --> 00:32:01.920 align:middle line:84%
The resolute desk
has a bottom drawer

00:32:01.920 --> 00:32:05.730 align:middle line:84%
full of gifts that the
president gives to visitors

00:32:05.730 --> 00:32:08.160 align:middle line:84%
and they're arranged
in priority order,

00:32:08.160 --> 00:32:11.320 align:middle line:84%
for the cheap stuff at the front
and the really expensive stuff

00:32:11.320 --> 00:32:12.280 align:middle line:90%
at the back.

00:32:12.280 --> 00:32:16.450 align:middle line:84%
So Nixon said to Elvis, I
want to give you a gift.

00:32:16.450 --> 00:32:18.850 align:middle line:84%
So Elvis got up out of
his chair and went around

00:32:18.850 --> 00:32:22.930 align:middle line:84%
the back of the desk instead
of waiting for the president.

00:32:22.930 --> 00:32:24.700 align:middle line:90%
And he goes and pulls up--

00:32:24.700 --> 00:32:27.070 align:middle line:84%
I forget what he pulled
out-- but went right

00:32:27.070 --> 00:32:29.170 align:middle line:84%
to the back of the
drawer and pulled out

00:32:29.170 --> 00:32:30.362 align:middle line:90%
the most expensive stuff.

00:32:30.362 --> 00:32:31.570 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: The good stuff.

00:32:31.570 --> 00:32:32.230 align:middle line:90%
Yeah.

00:32:32.230 --> 00:32:34.270 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHS]

00:32:34.270 --> 00:32:38.140 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: So we have the
letter in the Nixon Library.

00:32:38.140 --> 00:32:42.040 align:middle line:84%
We have the letter that Elvis
wrote and wonderful pictures.

00:32:42.040 --> 00:32:45.850 align:middle line:84%
And the picture is on shower
curtains, coffee mugs.

00:32:45.850 --> 00:32:48.340 align:middle line:90%
It's on T-shirts, sweatshirts.

00:32:48.340 --> 00:32:50.770 align:middle line:90%
It's on everything.

00:32:50.770 --> 00:32:55.600 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: And so
along those lines,

00:32:55.600 --> 00:32:59.710 align:middle line:84%
where do Presidential records
and Presidential papers

00:32:59.710 --> 00:33:03.430 align:middle line:90%
fit in to all of this?

00:33:03.430 --> 00:33:08.260 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: As of 1978,
because President Nixon

00:33:08.260 --> 00:33:12.670 align:middle line:84%
considered his papers
private, not public--

00:33:12.670 --> 00:33:14.710 align:middle line:90%
and the whole Watergate thing--

00:33:14.710 --> 00:33:18.610 align:middle line:84%
Congress decided we need
to codify this and make

00:33:18.610 --> 00:33:21.110 align:middle line:84%
it clear that Presidential
records are public records.

00:33:21.110 --> 00:33:24.430 align:middle line:84%
So they belong to the
federal government.

00:33:24.430 --> 00:33:28.150 align:middle line:84%
And the way it
works is the records

00:33:28.150 --> 00:33:32.320 align:middle line:84%
are maintained in
the White House

00:33:32.320 --> 00:33:35.170 align:middle line:90%
during the administration.

00:33:35.170 --> 00:33:38.650 align:middle line:84%
And it isn't until
the inauguration

00:33:38.650 --> 00:33:41.950 align:middle line:84%
of the new president,
during that ceremony,

00:33:41.950 --> 00:33:45.280 align:middle line:84%
that the records are transferred
to the National Archives.

00:33:45.280 --> 00:33:48.718 align:middle line:84%
They stay in the White
House until then.

00:33:48.718 --> 00:33:51.010 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: So you kind of
touched on it a little bit

00:33:51.010 --> 00:33:54.640 align:middle line:84%
about the personal ownership
versus the public ownership,

00:33:54.640 --> 00:33:57.130 align:middle line:90%
because for centuries--

00:33:57.130 --> 00:34:01.150 align:middle line:84%
I mean 1 and 1/2
centuries, 150 years--

00:34:01.150 --> 00:34:03.822 align:middle line:84%
Presidential papers were
considered personal property.

00:34:03.822 --> 00:34:06.280 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: And they're
scattered all over the country.

00:34:06.280 --> 00:34:06.760 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah.

00:34:06.760 --> 00:34:09.010 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: Library of
Congress has a lot of them.

00:34:09.010 --> 00:34:12.790 align:middle line:84%
But it wasn't until
FDR, actually,

00:34:12.790 --> 00:34:15.429 align:middle line:84%
who had the first
Presidential Library.

00:34:15.429 --> 00:34:18.820 align:middle line:84%
I'm convinced that FDR
was a closet archivist,

00:34:18.820 --> 00:34:20.469 align:middle line:90%
because he really paid--

00:34:20.469 --> 00:34:22.060 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: There are a lot
of them out there, actually.

00:34:22.060 --> 00:34:23.143 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: I know it.

00:34:23.143 --> 00:34:25.330 align:middle line:84%
He really paid attention
to organization.

00:34:25.330 --> 00:34:29.139 align:middle line:84%
And he actually-- you probably
don't know this-- but,

00:34:29.139 --> 00:34:33.909 align:middle line:84%
you archivists, he created
the prototype phase box

00:34:33.909 --> 00:34:35.675 align:middle line:84%
that you now store
your records in.

00:34:35.675 --> 00:34:36.550 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Really?

00:34:36.550 --> 00:34:38.560 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: It
wasn't with acid free--

00:34:38.560 --> 00:34:39.580 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: The archivists
are really excited about this.

00:34:39.580 --> 00:34:40.639 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:34:40.639 --> 00:34:43.097 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: It wasn't with
acid free paper or anything,

00:34:43.097 --> 00:34:44.710 align:middle line:90%
but it's the same box.

00:34:44.710 --> 00:34:46.460 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: I read
an interesting thing.

00:34:46.460 --> 00:34:49.610 align:middle line:84%
So I want to touch on this issue
of the Presidential Libraries,

00:34:49.610 --> 00:34:51.300 align:middle line:84%
because you mentioned
it with Truman.

00:34:51.300 --> 00:34:52.842 align:middle line:84%
And you've talked
about a little bit.

00:34:52.842 --> 00:34:55.130 align:middle line:84%
But a little tidbit that
I found out about FDR,

00:34:55.130 --> 00:34:57.800 align:middle line:84%
so Franklin Roosevelt
was the first president

00:34:57.800 --> 00:35:00.240 align:middle line:84%
to start a Presidential
Library, right.

00:35:00.240 --> 00:35:02.240 align:middle line:84%
So it's to look at
everything and say, Wow, I've

00:35:02.240 --> 00:35:03.830 align:middle line:90%
got a lot of cool stuff.

00:35:03.830 --> 00:35:06.270 align:middle line:84%
I should make it accessible
to the American people.

00:35:06.270 --> 00:35:08.630 align:middle line:84%
And so he established
a library and a museum.

00:35:08.630 --> 00:35:13.430 align:middle line:84%
And he had tons of gifts,
and memorabilia, and chairs,

00:35:13.430 --> 00:35:14.390 align:middle line:90%
and I don't know what.

00:35:14.390 --> 00:35:17.420 align:middle line:84%
And the archivist who was
working with him said, do you

00:35:17.420 --> 00:35:18.943 align:middle line:90%
really need all of this?

00:35:18.943 --> 00:35:21.110 align:middle line:84%
Do you really want to put
all of this in the museum?

00:35:21.110 --> 00:35:23.630 align:middle line:84%
And he said, if people
are going to pay a quarter

00:35:23.630 --> 00:35:27.950 align:middle line:84%
to come to this library,
they need to see some stuff.

00:35:27.950 --> 00:35:29.630 align:middle line:90%
They're paying a quarter.

00:35:29.630 --> 00:35:32.960 align:middle line:84%
But could you talk a little
bit about what a Presidential

00:35:32.960 --> 00:35:37.010 align:middle line:84%
Library is versus the
Presidential Records

00:35:37.010 --> 00:35:38.527 align:middle line:84%
that go into the
National Archives

00:35:38.527 --> 00:35:39.860 align:middle line:90%
and what that system looks like.

00:35:39.860 --> 00:35:41.330 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO:
It's a combination.

00:35:41.330 --> 00:35:44.430 align:middle line:90%
It's artifacts and records.

00:35:44.430 --> 00:35:50.890 align:middle line:84%
So state gifts and lots of
gifts from the American public

00:35:50.890 --> 00:35:54.100 align:middle line:84%
all become part of-- those
are considered records--

00:35:54.100 --> 00:35:58.210 align:middle line:84%
and become part of the museum
aspect of the Presidential

00:35:58.210 --> 00:35:59.230 align:middle line:90%
Library.

00:35:59.230 --> 00:36:01.600 align:middle line:90%
We have a wonderful--

00:36:01.600 --> 00:36:05.320 align:middle line:84%
the largest collection of
macaroni paintings in the world

00:36:05.320 --> 00:36:07.420 align:middle line:84%
are in our
Presidential Libraries.

00:36:07.420 --> 00:36:10.450 align:middle line:84%
We have every shoe that
Hillary Clinton ever wore.

00:36:10.450 --> 00:36:12.280 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:36:12.280 --> 00:36:17.350 align:middle line:84%
We have a lot of First
Lady [LAUGHS] wardrobes.

00:36:17.350 --> 00:36:22.295 align:middle line:84%
And Hillary Clinton is still
delivering shoes to the Clinton

00:36:22.295 --> 00:36:23.170 align:middle line:90%
Presidential Library.

00:36:23.170 --> 00:36:26.480 align:middle line:90%


00:36:26.480 --> 00:36:28.240 align:middle line:90%
Very strange collections.

00:36:28.240 --> 00:36:30.190 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: But the
public can visit them.

00:36:30.190 --> 00:36:30.610 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Yes.

00:36:30.610 --> 00:36:31.930 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: And
they have exhibitions.

00:36:31.930 --> 00:36:32.930 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Exactly.

00:36:32.930 --> 00:36:34.600 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: And you
can see the shoes.

00:36:34.600 --> 00:36:35.940 align:middle line:90%
Can you try them on though?

00:36:35.940 --> 00:36:37.720 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: No.

00:36:37.720 --> 00:36:39.638 align:middle line:84%
After I had done my
first tour of all

00:36:39.638 --> 00:36:41.680 align:middle line:84%
the Presidential Libraries
and seen all of these,

00:36:41.680 --> 00:36:43.270 align:middle line:84%
I started putting
things together

00:36:43.270 --> 00:36:47.900 align:middle line:84%
and threatened to do a first
lady shoe exhibit from--

00:36:47.900 --> 00:36:50.150 align:middle line:84%
DIANE DALLIS-COMENTALE: I
think the Met did an exhibit

00:36:50.150 --> 00:36:51.540 align:middle line:90%
on first lady dresses.

00:36:51.540 --> 00:36:53.570 align:middle line:84%
So I don't know why
you wouldn't do shoes.

00:36:53.570 --> 00:36:54.380 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: We
could do that too.

00:36:54.380 --> 00:36:54.850 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah.

00:36:54.850 --> 00:36:55.760 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: Yeah,
we could do that too.

00:36:55.760 --> 00:36:58.790 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: So one of the
things that you also mentioned,

00:36:58.790 --> 00:37:01.220 align:middle line:84%
that is in the
event description,

00:37:01.220 --> 00:37:07.160 align:middle line:84%
that I do want to talk about is
the theme for IU's Themester.

00:37:07.160 --> 00:37:09.860 align:middle line:84%
