This last Themester is
Lux et Veritas, right,

00:37:09.860 --> 00:37:13.880 align:middle line:84%
which translates
into light and truth.

00:37:13.880 --> 00:37:18.740 align:middle line:84%
It's also actually part of
the motto on the official seal

00:37:18.740 --> 00:37:20.810 align:middle line:90%
of Indiana University.

00:37:20.810 --> 00:37:23.660 align:middle line:84%
And I know that when
my colleagues first

00:37:23.660 --> 00:37:26.690 align:middle line:84%
had this idea of celebrating
this last Themester

00:37:26.690 --> 00:37:31.610 align:middle line:84%
and inviting you, they had this
really nice idea of shining

00:37:31.610 --> 00:37:37.970 align:middle line:84%
the light of truth onto records,
and history, and archives,

00:37:37.970 --> 00:37:40.230 align:middle line:90%
and things along those lines.

00:37:40.230 --> 00:37:42.440 align:middle line:84%
And you've talked
about open government

00:37:42.440 --> 00:37:43.820 align:middle line:90%
and the open government system.

00:37:43.820 --> 00:37:47.640 align:middle line:84%
Can you talk a little
bit of what that means.

00:37:47.640 --> 00:37:51.210 align:middle line:84%
What does open government
mean, and why is it important?

00:37:51.210 --> 00:37:53.460 align:middle line:84%
Why is it an
important principle?

00:37:53.460 --> 00:37:58.370 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: So in the Obama
language for open government,

00:37:58.370 --> 00:38:01.880 align:middle line:84%
it was transparency,
participation,

00:38:01.880 --> 00:38:02.720 align:middle line:90%
and collaboration.

00:38:02.720 --> 00:38:07.190 align:middle line:84%
Those are the three linchpins
of what open government means.

00:38:07.190 --> 00:38:10.190 align:middle line:84%
And for the National
Archives, we

00:38:10.190 --> 00:38:12.440 align:middle line:84%
tried hard to figure
out ways that we

00:38:12.440 --> 00:38:14.580 align:middle line:90%
could fulfill that vision.

00:38:14.580 --> 00:38:17.030 align:middle line:84%
So on his first day in
office, the president

00:38:17.030 --> 00:38:21.440 align:middle line:84%
met with his senior staff
and made the statement

00:38:21.440 --> 00:38:24.050 align:middle line:84%
that the government doesn't
have all the answers,

00:38:24.050 --> 00:38:27.110 align:middle line:84%
and we need to figure out ways
to engage the American public

00:38:27.110 --> 00:38:28.830 align:middle line:90%
in doing our work.

00:38:28.830 --> 00:38:32.150 align:middle line:84%
So we took that very seriously
at the National Archives

00:38:32.150 --> 00:38:34.100 align:middle line:84%
and worked on and
thought about ways

00:38:34.100 --> 00:38:37.400 align:middle line:84%
that we could engage
the public in the work

00:38:37.400 --> 00:38:41.030 align:middle line:84%
that we do, which resulted in
the creation of the Citizen

00:38:41.030 --> 00:38:45.560 align:middle line:84%
Archivist project, where we have
opportunities for the public

00:38:45.560 --> 00:38:50.790 align:middle line:84%
to help us, in a number of ways,
in making access to our records

00:38:50.790 --> 00:38:51.610 align:middle line:90%
better.

00:38:51.610 --> 00:38:54.390 align:middle line:84%
So, as you probably
know, cursive

00:38:54.390 --> 00:38:57.030 align:middle line:84%
isn't taught much
in schools anymore.

00:38:57.030 --> 00:39:01.470 align:middle line:84%
And about 80% of the Federal
Records are in cursive.

00:39:01.470 --> 00:39:04.800 align:middle line:84%
So we have kids now,
and their parents

00:39:04.800 --> 00:39:07.620 align:middle line:84%
in lots of cases, who
can't read these records.

00:39:07.620 --> 00:39:09.510 align:middle line:84%
And in fact, I was
talking to a couple

00:39:09.510 --> 00:39:12.270 align:middle line:84%
of adults last night who
couldn't read records,

00:39:12.270 --> 00:39:13.287 align:middle line:90%
couldn't read cursive.

00:39:13.287 --> 00:39:15.120 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Or even
from the 19th century,

00:39:15.120 --> 00:39:18.030 align:middle line:84%
even if you can read cursive,
it's a different kind

00:39:18.030 --> 00:39:18.830 align:middle line:90%
and it's--

00:39:18.830 --> 00:39:20.580 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: Don't
give me any excuses.

00:39:20.580 --> 00:39:21.747 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: OK, all right.

00:39:21.747 --> 00:39:22.482 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:39:22.482 --> 00:39:23.190 align:middle line:90%
I take that back.

00:39:23.190 --> 00:39:24.990 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: So we
have loaded thousands

00:39:24.990 --> 00:39:27.510 align:middle line:84%
of records in the Citizen
Archivist Dashboard

00:39:27.510 --> 00:39:29.700 align:middle line:84%
and you can go in and
transcribe for us.

00:39:29.700 --> 00:39:31.620 align:middle line:84%
And we've got folks
from, actually,

00:39:31.620 --> 00:39:34.750 align:middle line:84%
around the world who are
participating in this.

00:39:34.750 --> 00:39:38.790 align:middle line:84%
And to date, we have I think
the figure is something

00:39:38.790 --> 00:39:44.655 align:middle line:84%
like 250 million transcriptions
have been done of our records.

00:39:44.655 --> 00:39:47.280 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: And this is just,
when you say Citizen Archivist,

00:39:47.280 --> 00:39:52.260 align:middle line:84%
this is just people,
just the public.

00:39:52.260 --> 00:39:55.350 align:middle line:84%
Well, I mean, these are not
necessarily employees of NARA.

00:39:55.350 --> 00:39:57.142 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: There's
a wonderful nursing

00:39:57.142 --> 00:39:59.980 align:middle line:84%
home in Massachusetts that
has adopted this project.

00:39:59.980 --> 00:40:01.472 align:middle line:84%
And they do they
do transcriptions.

00:40:01.472 --> 00:40:03.180 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: So this
is for anyone who's

00:40:03.180 --> 00:40:05.130 align:middle line:90%
interested in getting involved.

00:40:05.130 --> 00:40:06.270 align:middle line:90%
Is it still going?

00:40:06.270 --> 00:40:07.470 align:middle line:90%
Can people still get in--

00:40:07.470 --> 00:40:07.920 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Oh Yeah

00:40:07.920 --> 00:40:09.390 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: How they get
involved in the project?

00:40:09.390 --> 00:40:10.557 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Archives.gov

00:40:10.557 --> 00:40:12.610 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Archives.gov OK.

00:40:12.610 --> 00:40:15.300 align:middle line:84%
Do you do crowdsourcing
like, with photographs?

00:40:15.300 --> 00:40:16.800 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: Oh
yeah, we do that.

00:40:16.800 --> 00:40:17.300 align:middle line:90%
Yeah.

00:40:17.300 --> 00:40:19.587 align:middle line:84%
There are several
different options.

00:40:19.587 --> 00:40:20.670 align:middle line:90%
You can do transcriptions.

00:40:20.670 --> 00:40:22.680 align:middle line:90%
You can tag photos.

00:40:22.680 --> 00:40:25.020 align:middle line:84%
As I said, we have 43
million photographs

00:40:25.020 --> 00:40:27.430 align:middle line:90%
and not very well described.

00:40:27.430 --> 00:40:30.180 align:middle line:84%
So we've loaded
thousands of photographs

00:40:30.180 --> 00:40:34.410 align:middle line:84%
where people are tagging people
that they recognize, or places

00:40:34.410 --> 00:40:37.470 align:middle line:84%
if they recognize, or whatever
information they might

00:40:37.470 --> 00:40:41.040 align:middle line:90%
have about the photograph.

00:40:41.040 --> 00:40:43.200 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: So what
is the result of this.

00:40:43.200 --> 00:40:46.830 align:middle line:84%
How many people have been
involved as Citizen Archivists.

00:40:46.830 --> 00:40:50.145 align:middle line:84%
And has NARA been
pleased with the results?

00:40:50.145 --> 00:40:51.770 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: The
results have been--

00:40:51.770 --> 00:40:53.103 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: How's the quality?

00:40:53.103 --> 00:40:55.320 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: I can't
give you numbers of people.

00:40:55.320 --> 00:40:59.330 align:middle line:84%
But we've been very
pleased with the quality

00:40:59.330 --> 00:41:00.800 align:middle line:84%
of the transcriptions
and each one

00:41:00.800 --> 00:41:04.680 align:middle line:84%
is checked to make sure
that it's accurate.

00:41:04.680 --> 00:41:08.540 align:middle line:84%
Another way that we've focused
on-- this came up in my meeting

00:41:08.540 --> 00:41:10.040 align:middle line:90%
with the students today.

00:41:10.040 --> 00:41:13.220 align:middle line:90%


00:41:13.220 --> 00:41:18.740 align:middle line:84%
Every attempt is to make our
content accessible in any way

00:41:18.740 --> 00:41:19.500 align:middle line:90%
we possibly can.

00:41:19.500 --> 00:41:25.040 align:middle line:84%
So we've devoted a lot of work,
time, and effort on Wikipedia.

00:41:25.040 --> 00:41:25.790 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah

00:41:25.790 --> 00:41:28.415 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: Hired the first
federal Wikipedian in residence

00:41:28.415 --> 00:41:31.400 align:middle line:84%
was part of the
National Archives staff,

00:41:31.400 --> 00:41:36.020 align:middle line:84%
who had the dual role of
helping us create those links

00:41:36.020 --> 00:41:40.200 align:middle line:84%
but also educating the staff
about the power of Wikipedia.

00:41:40.200 --> 00:41:48.380 align:middle line:84%
So now our processing
folks link record groups

00:41:48.380 --> 00:41:52.400 align:middle line:90%
to articles in Wikipedia.

00:41:52.400 --> 00:41:56.030 align:middle line:84%
And there are probably
in the neighborhood

00:41:56.030 --> 00:42:01.010 align:middle line:84%
of 4,000 to 5,000
Wikipedia records that

00:42:01.010 --> 00:42:05.360 align:middle line:84%
have content that have links
from the National Archives.

00:42:05.360 --> 00:42:13.160 align:middle line:84%
And we get three billion hits a
year from those Wikipedia hits.

00:42:13.160 --> 00:42:15.050 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Well,
and also, you also

00:42:15.050 --> 00:42:19.970 align:middle line:84%
initiated a huge social
media initiative as well.

00:42:19.970 --> 00:42:21.410 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Yeah.

00:42:21.410 --> 00:42:24.980 align:middle line:84%
When I was coming to
Washington for one

00:42:24.980 --> 00:42:28.100 align:middle line:84%
of those meetings on the Hill
with the Senate Committee.

00:42:28.100 --> 00:42:31.550 align:middle line:84%
I'm not even the archivist yet,
but I'm reading the New York

00:42:31.550 --> 00:42:35.780 align:middle line:84%
Times and there's this article
about the White House letting

00:42:35.780 --> 00:42:40.370 align:middle line:84%
an RFP with help on
their social media.

00:42:40.370 --> 00:42:41.150 align:middle line:90%
Archiving.

00:42:41.150 --> 00:42:42.170 align:middle line:90%
Archiving social media.

00:42:42.170 --> 00:42:43.310 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Oh,
archiving social media.

00:42:43.310 --> 00:42:45.440 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: And I'm saying
to myself, oh wait a minute.

00:42:45.440 --> 00:42:46.770 align:middle line:90%
Where's the National Archives?

00:42:46.770 --> 00:42:48.680 align:middle line:90%
Why aren't they all over this?

00:42:48.680 --> 00:42:51.600 align:middle line:84%
And it turns out that the
National Archives wasn't doing

00:42:51.600 --> 00:42:53.860 align:middle line:90%
anything with social media.

00:42:53.860 --> 00:42:57.240 align:middle line:90%
And this is 2009.

00:42:57.240 --> 00:43:00.180 align:middle line:84%
And I discovered that there
was a small group of folks

00:43:00.180 --> 00:43:03.690 align:middle line:84%
who were interested
in social media

00:43:03.690 --> 00:43:09.690 align:middle line:84%
and were meeting in secret
to talk about their dreams

00:43:09.690 --> 00:43:12.750 align:middle line:84%
about how they might
use social media.

00:43:12.750 --> 00:43:15.855 align:middle line:84%
And I heard about
this, and I walked

00:43:15.855 --> 00:43:16.980 align:middle line:90%
into one of their meetings.

00:43:16.980 --> 00:43:19.140 align:middle line:84%
And they thought
they were busted.

00:43:19.140 --> 00:43:20.580 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:43:20.580 --> 00:43:22.560 align:middle line:84%
And we sat down and had
a great conversation.

00:43:22.560 --> 00:43:27.810 align:middle line:84%
And at that meeting I
authorized the purchase

00:43:27.810 --> 00:43:38.310 align:middle line:84%
of iPads and iPhones,
25 to fool around.

00:43:38.310 --> 00:43:40.170 align:middle line:90%
And let's get started here.

00:43:40.170 --> 00:43:45.210 align:middle line:84%
And the next morning I got a
call from my CIO, who said,

00:43:45.210 --> 00:43:47.310 align:middle line:84%
I understand you want
iPads and iPhones.

00:43:47.310 --> 00:43:49.030 align:middle line:84%
And I said, Yeah,
isn't it exciting.

00:43:49.030 --> 00:43:51.040 align:middle line:84%
We're going to experiment
and blah, blah, blah.

00:43:51.040 --> 00:43:54.790 align:middle line:84%
And she said, well, you know, we
don't support that technology.

00:43:54.790 --> 00:43:55.980 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Oh.

00:43:55.980 --> 00:43:57.007 align:middle line:90%
IPads and iPhones?

00:43:57.007 --> 00:43:58.590 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: Then
I said, you know,

00:43:58.590 --> 00:44:00.150 align:middle line:84%
the best part about
this technology

00:44:00.150 --> 00:44:01.483 align:middle line:90%
is it doesn't need your support.

00:44:01.483 --> 00:44:04.770 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:44:04.770 --> 00:44:09.330 align:middle line:84%
And the next call I got
was from acquisitions,

00:44:09.330 --> 00:44:11.370 align:middle line:84%
I understand you want
iPhones and iPads.

00:44:11.370 --> 00:44:12.467 align:middle line:90%
I say, isn't it exciting.

00:44:12.467 --> 00:44:13.800 align:middle line:90%
We're going to be experimenting.

00:44:13.800 --> 00:44:14.367 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:44:14.367 --> 00:44:15.450 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: I like this.

00:44:15.450 --> 00:44:16.950 align:middle line:90%
Just keep repeating it.

00:44:16.950 --> 00:44:18.365 align:middle line:90%
Yeah.

00:44:18.365 --> 00:44:19.990 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO:
That'll take 13 months.

00:44:19.990 --> 00:44:21.750 align:middle line:90%
13 months.

00:44:21.750 --> 00:44:23.520 align:middle line:84%
I said, no, that's
not good enough.

00:44:23.520 --> 00:44:25.320 align:middle line:90%
Uh-Uh, that doesn't work for me.

00:44:25.320 --> 00:44:27.370 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:44:27.370 --> 00:44:29.340 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: I
actually had a student--

00:44:29.340 --> 00:44:31.110 align:middle line:90%
I hope she's here today, but--

00:44:31.110 --> 00:44:33.690 align:middle line:84%
contact me yesterday
from the IDS

00:44:33.690 --> 00:44:36.270 align:middle line:84%
with the Indiana Daily Student,
which is a student newspaper.

00:44:36.270 --> 00:44:38.970 align:middle line:84%
And she asked me a really
interesting question.

00:44:38.970 --> 00:44:43.350 align:middle line:84%
She asked me what I found
most interesting or inspiring

00:44:43.350 --> 00:44:44.190 align:middle line:90%
about you.

00:44:44.190 --> 00:44:48.760 align:middle line:84%
And I have to say that
my answer was actually

00:44:48.760 --> 00:44:51.670 align:middle line:84%
the "Gighy" or
"Jiphy," depending

00:44:51.670 --> 00:44:54.610 align:middle line:84%
on how you pronounce it, the
Giphy Channel for the National

00:44:54.610 --> 00:44:55.480 align:middle line:90%
Archives.

00:44:55.480 --> 00:44:57.440 align:middle line:90%
Because I checked it out.

00:44:57.440 --> 00:44:58.030 align:middle line:90%
It's amazing.

00:44:58.030 --> 00:45:02.350 align:middle line:84%
There are 1,500 JIFs
or GIFs, depending

00:45:02.350 --> 00:45:07.390 align:middle line:84%
on your preference,
that have been uploaded

00:45:07.390 --> 00:45:11.170 align:middle line:90%
and over 5.3 billion views.

00:45:11.170 --> 00:45:12.220 align:middle line:90%
Billion.

00:45:12.220 --> 00:45:16.780 align:middle line:84%
And it's amazing because there
are things from World War One,

00:45:16.780 --> 00:45:20.530 align:middle line:84%
World War Two, but
also space exploration,

00:45:20.530 --> 00:45:24.940 align:middle line:84%
and the Apollo 11 mission,
and civil rights movement,

00:45:24.940 --> 00:45:27.190 align:middle line:90%
and women's suffrage.

00:45:27.190 --> 00:45:31.630 align:middle line:84%
But also kids
sledding, and holidays,

00:45:31.630 --> 00:45:35.783 align:middle line:84%
and my favorite, which is
the dancing dogs, Waffles

00:45:35.783 --> 00:45:36.325 align:middle line:90%
and Dempsey--

00:45:36.325 --> 00:45:37.240 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:45:37.240 --> 00:45:38.740 align:middle line:90%
--who are wearing little tutus.

00:45:38.740 --> 00:45:43.240 align:middle line:84%
And what I said
was that, to me it

00:45:43.240 --> 00:45:47.350 align:middle line:84%
is making the federal government
and the National Archives

00:45:47.350 --> 00:45:49.120 align:middle line:90%
more accessible.

00:45:49.120 --> 00:45:53.290 align:middle line:84%
And it is saying to
people, everyone's welcome.

00:45:53.290 --> 00:45:58.450 align:middle line:84%
We're not just this imposing
building on Pennsylvania Avenue

00:45:58.450 --> 00:45:59.800 align:middle line:90%
but we're you.

00:45:59.800 --> 00:46:01.240 align:middle line:90%
We're About you.

00:46:01.240 --> 00:46:03.970 align:middle line:84%
So is this kind of
something that you felt--

00:46:03.970 --> 00:46:08.830 align:middle line:84%
how do you feel that this
helped with NARA's image?

00:46:08.830 --> 00:46:10.840 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: First of
all, it was unleashing

00:46:10.840 --> 00:46:13.630 align:middle line:84%
the talent within the
Agency that these folks have

00:46:13.630 --> 00:46:16.570 align:middle line:84%
been dreaming about things
to do with social media.

00:46:16.570 --> 00:46:21.550 align:middle line:84%
As I said, in 2009 we were not
on any social media platforms.

00:46:21.550 --> 00:46:23.440 align:middle line:84%
And the argument I
made with the staff

00:46:23.440 --> 00:46:26.380 align:middle line:84%
was, we are responsible
for providing

00:46:26.380 --> 00:46:30.910 align:middle line:84%
guidance to the agencies
about the records

00:46:30.910 --> 00:46:34.130 align:middle line:84%
implications of their
use of social media.

00:46:34.130 --> 00:46:36.430 align:middle line:84%
And if we're not using
this stuff ourselves,

00:46:36.430 --> 00:46:38.930 align:middle line:84%
how are we possibly
going to do that?

00:46:38.930 --> 00:46:47.380 align:middle line:84%
So we're now on 16 platforms
and the staff is energized,

00:46:47.380 --> 00:46:51.370 align:middle line:84%
and it has spread
to State Archives

00:46:51.370 --> 00:46:55.792 align:middle line:84%
and other archives have been
following what we're doing.

00:46:55.792 --> 00:46:57.250 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Well,
and I noticed--

00:46:57.250 --> 00:46:58.870 align:middle line:84%
and we'll start
with the questions--

00:46:58.870 --> 00:47:04.840 align:middle line:84%
but I also noticed that the
Trump Presidential Library

00:47:04.840 --> 00:47:06.638 align:middle line:90%
has an archive of his tweets.

00:47:06.638 --> 00:47:07.930 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Yes, of course.

00:47:07.930 --> 00:47:11.860 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: So social
media is actually

00:47:11.860 --> 00:47:15.010 align:middle line:84%
an important social
phenomenon that

00:47:15.010 --> 00:47:18.730 align:middle line:84%
is woven into the nation's
history and the Presidential

00:47:18.730 --> 00:47:20.350 align:middle line:90%
Records.

00:47:20.350 --> 00:47:22.760 align:middle line:84%
All right, so now we will
turn to y'all's questions.

00:47:22.760 --> 00:47:27.010 align:middle line:84%
So the first one for you
is, while we narrowly

00:47:27.010 --> 00:47:30.700 align:middle line:84%
avoided a government shutdown,
you saw the National Archives

00:47:30.700 --> 00:47:32.590 align:middle line:90%
through a few shutdowns.

00:47:32.590 --> 00:47:38.920 align:middle line:84%
How did these impact the work
of NARA, short and long term?

00:47:38.920 --> 00:47:41.590 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: It's
a horrible situation

00:47:41.590 --> 00:47:45.970 align:middle line:84%
because we have no idea how long
the shutdown is going to last.

00:47:45.970 --> 00:47:49.490 align:middle line:90%
That the staff by and large--

00:47:49.490 --> 00:47:52.360 align:middle line:84%
we have, for the National
Archives it's 3,000 people

00:47:52.360 --> 00:47:57.370 align:middle line:90%
in 42 facilities in 17 states--

00:47:57.370 --> 00:47:59.830 align:middle line:84%
most of them live
paycheck to paycheck.

00:47:59.830 --> 00:48:02.650 align:middle line:84%
They're not getting paid,
and they have no idea

00:48:02.650 --> 00:48:05.290 align:middle line:90%
how long this is going to last.

00:48:05.290 --> 00:48:08.920 align:middle line:84%
For the longer ones, and we've
been through some longer ones,

00:48:08.920 --> 00:48:13.060 align:middle line:84%
people have actually left
and taken other jobs.

00:48:13.060 --> 00:48:18.430 align:middle line:84%
But the damage it
does to people feeling

00:48:18.430 --> 00:48:21.940 align:middle line:84%
good about working for the
government and the damage

00:48:21.940 --> 00:48:25.262 align:middle line:84%
it does in recruiting
is really serious.

00:48:25.262 --> 00:48:27.220 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: We talked
about this this morning

00:48:27.220 --> 00:48:29.260 align:middle line:84%
because my mother
actually worked

00:48:29.260 --> 00:48:33.100 align:middle line:84%
for the federal government for
the Department of Agriculture.

00:48:33.100 --> 00:48:37.660 align:middle line:84%
And she had to live
through several shutdowns

00:48:37.660 --> 00:48:38.840 align:middle line:90%
as a single mother.

00:48:38.840 --> 00:48:41.650 align:middle line:84%
And so I've
experienced this, so.

00:48:41.650 --> 00:48:43.330 align:middle line:90%
Yeah.

00:48:43.330 --> 00:48:45.550 align:middle line:84%
What you're saying about
tarnishing kind of work--

00:48:45.550 --> 00:48:47.300 align:middle line:90%
anyway, all right.

00:48:47.300 --> 00:48:47.900 align:middle line:90%
Next question,

00:48:47.900 --> 00:48:49.040 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:48:49.040 --> 00:48:51.620 align:middle line:84%
My students are currently
reading and thinking

00:48:51.620 --> 00:48:52.670 align:middle line:90%
about archives.

00:48:52.670 --> 00:48:55.160 align:middle line:84%
It's a history gateway
course but they

00:48:55.160 --> 00:48:59.630 align:middle line:84%
are deeply concerned about
access to historical materials.

00:48:59.630 --> 00:49:03.560 align:middle line:84%
What was your role in getting
materials into the archives

00:49:03.560 --> 00:49:06.320 align:middle line:84%
from various departments
of the government?

00:49:06.320 --> 00:49:10.040 align:middle line:90%


00:49:10.040 --> 00:49:14.200 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: So way
back at the beginning,

00:49:14.200 --> 00:49:18.310 align:middle line:84%
when FDR signed the legislation
and created the National

00:49:18.310 --> 00:49:20.380 align:middle line:84%
Archives, he really
took-- as you

00:49:20.380 --> 00:49:23.410 align:middle line:84%
know I made that crack about
him being a closet archivist.

00:49:23.410 --> 00:49:27.370 align:middle line:84%
But he really took an
interest in the archives,

00:49:27.370 --> 00:49:30.460 align:middle line:84%
recruited the first
archivist, and made

00:49:30.460 --> 00:49:34.930 align:middle line:84%
sure that archivist got what
he needed in terms of support.

00:49:34.930 --> 00:49:38.050 align:middle line:84%
And that first archivist had
the job of wandering around town

00:49:38.050 --> 00:49:39.760 align:middle line:84%
and figuring out where
the records were,

00:49:39.760 --> 00:49:42.520 align:middle line:84%
and hiring a staff,
and an architect,

00:49:42.520 --> 00:49:44.455 align:middle line:90%
and all that kind of stuff.

00:49:44.455 --> 00:49:55.840 align:middle line:90%


00:49:55.840 --> 00:49:56.980 align:middle line:90%
Read that again.

00:49:56.980 --> 00:49:58.185 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Oh, so.

00:49:58.185 --> 00:49:59.560 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO:
There was a point

00:49:59.560 --> 00:50:03.550 align:middle line:84%
I was trying to make with
[LAUGHS] why we had to go back.

00:50:03.550 --> 00:50:04.810 align:middle line:90%
Oh, because, OK.

00:50:04.810 --> 00:50:08.680 align:middle line:84%
So then this poor
archivist had the job

00:50:08.680 --> 00:50:10.990 align:middle line:84%
of convincing agency
heads that this

00:50:10.990 --> 00:50:12.793 align:middle line:84%
is the new way of doing
business and you've

00:50:12.793 --> 00:50:13.960 align:middle line:90%
got to give me your records.

00:50:13.960 --> 00:50:16.910 align:middle line:84%
And you can imagine
how that went over.

00:50:16.910 --> 00:50:19.960 align:middle line:84%
So FDR had to have a cabinet
meeting where he kind of laid

00:50:19.960 --> 00:50:22.968 align:middle line:84%
down the law about
this is the way we're

00:50:22.968 --> 00:50:24.010 align:middle line:90%
going to do business now.

00:50:24.010 --> 00:50:28.480 align:middle line:84%
And the holdout then, and
to some extent still--

00:50:28.480 --> 00:50:30.910 align:middle line:84%
not that I want to throw
anyone under the bus--

00:50:30.910 --> 00:50:31.600 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: You're
retired, go ahead.

00:50:31.600 --> 00:50:32.980 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: --is
the State Department.

00:50:32.980 --> 00:50:33.688 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Oh.

00:50:33.688 --> 00:50:37.540 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: So state
was a unhappy camper

00:50:37.540 --> 00:50:40.720 align:middle line:84%
at the very beginning, and
FDR took it upon himself

00:50:40.720 --> 00:50:42.520 align:middle line:90%
one evening after hours.

00:50:42.520 --> 00:50:46.480 align:middle line:84%
He wrote about this, and I
was in hysterics reading it.

00:50:46.480 --> 00:50:49.360 align:middle line:84%
He had himself taken over
to the State Department.

00:50:49.360 --> 00:50:54.020 align:middle line:84%
And he describes this long
corridor with filing cabinets.

00:50:54.020 --> 00:50:56.900 align:middle line:84%
He wheels himself up
at random and pulls out

00:50:56.900 --> 00:51:03.170 align:middle line:84%
a file on Mongolian ponies to
demonstrate that you perhaps

00:51:03.170 --> 00:51:06.140 align:middle line:84%
don't need this file
on Mongolian ponies

00:51:06.140 --> 00:51:10.220 align:middle line:90%
here in the State Department.

00:51:10.220 --> 00:51:12.530 align:middle line:84%
And that's been a
problem ever since.

00:51:12.530 --> 00:51:16.730 align:middle line:90%
That some agencies are--

00:51:16.730 --> 00:51:20.210 align:middle line:84%
especially, I would say
the intelligence community.

00:51:20.210 --> 00:51:21.770 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah.

00:51:21.770 --> 00:51:25.580 align:middle line:84%
Yeah, I guess I can
understand this reticence

00:51:25.580 --> 00:51:28.070 align:middle line:84%
when they're dealing with
intelligence and classified

00:51:28.070 --> 00:51:28.770 align:middle line:90%
documents.

00:51:28.770 --> 00:51:31.640 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: So this
Mongolian Pony thing

00:51:31.640 --> 00:51:32.700 align:middle line:90%
bothered me.

00:51:32.700 --> 00:51:36.950 align:middle line:84%
And so I went to the staff
and said, so can you find it?

00:51:36.950 --> 00:51:37.880 align:middle line:90%
Do we have that?

00:51:37.880 --> 00:51:38.660 align:middle line:90%
We don't have it.

00:51:38.660 --> 00:51:39.500 align:middle line:90%
We don't have it.

00:51:39.500 --> 00:51:39.800 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah

00:51:39.800 --> 00:51:41.383 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: So
they still have it.

00:51:41.383 --> 00:51:44.730 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:51:44.730 --> 00:51:47.000 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Well, should
I submit a FOIA, Freedom

00:51:47.000 --> 00:51:48.320 align:middle line:90%
of Information Act request?

00:51:48.320 --> 00:51:49.190 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: That
would be fun, yeah.

00:51:49.190 --> 00:51:49.898 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: OK.

00:51:49.898 --> 00:51:50.840 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:51:50.840 --> 00:51:55.280 align:middle line:84%
How has the relationship between
historians and archivists

00:51:55.280 --> 00:51:57.965 align:middle line:84%
changed over the
course of your career?

00:51:57.965 --> 00:52:03.350 align:middle line:90%


00:52:03.350 --> 00:52:07.960 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: I think they
have better access to records

00:52:07.960 --> 00:52:12.160 align:middle line:90%
than they've had before.

00:52:12.160 --> 00:52:22.920 align:middle line:84%
I think we're good salespeople
for their product, what

00:52:22.920 --> 00:52:24.180 align:middle line:90%
they've written.

00:52:24.180 --> 00:52:30.480 align:middle line:84%
I made it a point to do public
programs with any historian who

00:52:30.480 --> 00:52:33.960 align:middle line:84%
used the records as a way of
demonstrating the value that we

00:52:33.960 --> 00:52:35.640 align:middle line:90%
bring.

00:52:35.640 --> 00:52:37.140 align:middle line:84%
And I think the
work that we've been

00:52:37.140 --> 00:52:39.810 align:middle line:84%
doing in terms of
digitizing records

00:52:39.810 --> 00:52:46.020 align:middle line:84%
has improved the speed with
which they can do research.

00:52:46.020 --> 00:52:48.480 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: And there's
actually a parenthetical

00:52:48.480 --> 00:52:51.510 align:middle line:84%
question here, where
the person says, here

00:52:51.510 --> 00:52:55.770 align:middle line:84%
at IU we collaborate more
as guardians of the past,

00:52:55.770 --> 00:53:02.160 align:middle line:84%
navigating a more political
and less resourced present day.

00:53:02.160 --> 00:53:03.390 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Interesting.

00:53:03.390 --> 00:53:04.500 align:middle line:84%
That's a good way
of phrasing it.

00:53:04.500 --> 00:53:05.400 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah.

00:53:05.400 --> 00:53:09.690 align:middle line:84%
So as Guardians of the past,
navigating a more political

00:53:09.690 --> 00:53:12.180 align:middle line:90%
and less resource present day.

00:53:12.180 --> 00:53:13.867 align:middle line:84%
Did you feel that
when you were--

00:53:13.867 --> 00:53:14.950 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Definitely

00:53:14.950 --> 00:53:15.430 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah, archivist?

00:53:15.430 --> 00:53:16.555 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Definitely.

00:53:16.555 --> 00:53:19.280 align:middle line:90%


00:53:19.280 --> 00:53:20.860 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Next
one, can you speak

00:53:20.860 --> 00:53:25.330 align:middle line:84%
about archives in the age
of extreme climate change?

00:53:25.330 --> 00:53:25.840 align:middle line:90%
Yeah.

00:53:25.840 --> 00:53:29.230 align:middle line:84%
How ready are American
archives for dealing

00:53:29.230 --> 00:53:33.086 align:middle line:84%
with natural disasters
and other kinds of things?

00:53:33.086 --> 00:53:34.120 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: [SIGHS]

00:53:34.120 --> 00:53:37.360 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:53:37.360 --> 00:53:39.830 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: I'm also
groaning inwardly, actually.

00:53:39.830 --> 00:53:42.070 align:middle line:90%
Yeah.

00:53:42.070 --> 00:53:43.900 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO:
It's a tough one.

00:53:43.900 --> 00:53:47.275 align:middle line:90%
How prepared are we?

00:53:47.275 --> 00:53:52.210 align:middle line:84%
We have all kinds of
guidelines and stuff

00:53:52.210 --> 00:54:00.790 align:middle line:84%
for natural disasters, but
when it hits, it's devastating.

00:54:00.790 --> 00:54:05.980 align:middle line:84%
And we're so overtaxed in
terms of space for collections

00:54:05.980 --> 00:54:09.700 align:middle line:84%
that we make bargains
with the devil

00:54:09.700 --> 00:54:14.390 align:middle line:84%
about how we store stuff
and over-stuff places.

00:54:14.390 --> 00:54:19.777 align:middle line:90%


00:54:19.777 --> 00:54:21.360 align:middle line:84%
And we're talking
about the originals,

00:54:21.360 --> 00:54:24.360 align:middle line:84%
and that's why every
digitization effort

00:54:24.360 --> 00:54:28.140 align:middle line:84%
is an opportunity to
preserve, to make sure

00:54:28.140 --> 00:54:31.500 align:middle line:84%
that the content is
available in another format,

00:54:31.500 --> 00:54:34.800 align:middle line:84%
in case there's some kind
of disaster like that.

00:54:34.800 --> 00:54:37.140 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah, and
also, I would add too

00:54:37.140 --> 00:54:41.670 align:middle line:84%
that there's not an equity,
in terms of resources,

00:54:41.670 --> 00:54:43.470 align:middle line:90%
to different archives.

00:54:43.470 --> 00:54:46.290 align:middle line:84%
The National Archives,
I'm assuming,

00:54:46.290 --> 00:54:52.230 align:middle line:84%
has state of the art
facilities and conditions.

00:54:52.230 --> 00:54:56.520 align:middle line:84%
Here at IU we have an amazing
auxiliary library facility

00:54:56.520 --> 00:54:58.180 align:middle line:84%
that has state of
the art conditions.

00:54:58.180 --> 00:55:02.490 align:middle line:84%
But then you've got historical
societies and small archives

00:55:02.490 --> 00:55:07.290 align:middle line:84%
in places where they
don't have that,

00:55:07.290 --> 00:55:11.790 align:middle line:84%
and it's much more disastrous
when some kind of disaster

00:55:11.790 --> 00:55:13.290 align:middle line:90%
hits, or a flood, or--

00:55:13.290 --> 00:55:14.400 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: And
they're much more frequent,

00:55:14.400 --> 00:55:16.025 align:middle line:84%
those disasters are
much more frequent.

00:55:16.025 --> 00:55:19.720 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah and they're
happening much more frequently.

00:55:19.720 --> 00:55:23.010 align:middle line:84%
So in a profession
that feels like we're

00:55:23.010 --> 00:55:27.570 align:middle line:84%
frequently asked to do more
with less, in your career,

00:55:27.570 --> 00:55:31.470 align:middle line:84%
how have you advocated
for appropriate staffing

00:55:31.470 --> 00:55:34.695 align:middle line:84%
and resource levels to
support archival work?

00:55:34.695 --> 00:55:39.250 align:middle line:90%


00:55:39.250 --> 00:55:44.350 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: Ooh that's--
from the very beginning,

00:55:44.350 --> 00:55:46.750 align:middle line:84%
archives aren't the
most important things

00:55:46.750 --> 00:55:53.140 align:middle line:84%
in people's and funders'
minds, administration's minds.

00:55:53.140 --> 00:55:54.430 align:middle line:90%
Archives aren't sexy.

00:55:54.430 --> 00:55:57.430 align:middle line:90%
Records aren't sexy.

00:55:57.430 --> 00:56:01.420 align:middle line:84%
So there has to be
some kind of link

00:56:01.420 --> 00:56:08.290 align:middle line:84%
to some initiative that
makes sense for the funding

00:56:08.290 --> 00:56:10.690 align:middle line:90%
opportunity.

00:56:10.690 --> 00:56:14.770 align:middle line:84%
Private foundations,
if you can demonstrate

00:56:14.770 --> 00:56:17.680 align:middle line:84%
that you have something
that's of value

00:56:17.680 --> 00:56:21.200 align:middle line:84%
to a private foundation,
at least in my experience,

00:56:21.200 --> 00:56:25.570 align:middle line:84%
that sends a signal
to the administration

00:56:25.570 --> 00:56:29.020 align:middle line:90%
funders that perhaps--

00:56:29.020 --> 00:56:33.760 align:middle line:84%
if there's a requirement
for a matching gift--

00:56:33.760 --> 00:56:37.630 align:middle line:84%
that this is an opportunity to
support something and create

00:56:37.630 --> 00:56:41.623 align:middle line:84%
something great that
distinguishes the institution.

00:56:41.623 --> 00:56:43.040 align:middle line:84%
We're always looking
for something

00:56:43.040 --> 00:56:48.620 align:middle line:84%
that would impress the funders,
the administration, that

00:56:48.620 --> 00:56:52.970 align:middle line:84%
would raise the profile
of the institution.

00:56:52.970 --> 00:56:56.660 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Can I
ask a related question.

00:56:56.660 --> 00:57:00.110 align:middle line:84%
So I'm assuming that most of
the funding of the National

00:57:00.110 --> 00:57:04.100 align:middle line:84%
Archives comes from
Congress from appropriations

00:57:04.100 --> 00:57:05.480 align:middle line:90%
bills and et cetera.

00:57:05.480 --> 00:57:07.958 align:middle line:84%
Does it cover all of the funding
for the National Archives?

00:57:07.958 --> 00:57:10.250 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: No, we have
a private foundation, also,

00:57:10.250 --> 00:57:11.210 align:middle line:90%
that raises money.

00:57:11.210 --> 00:57:14.240 align:middle line:84%
And all the education
programs, exhibits,

00:57:14.240 --> 00:57:17.900 align:middle line:84%
are funded by the
private foundation.

00:57:17.900 --> 00:57:20.990 align:middle line:84%
And the Presidential Libraries
have private foundations also.

00:57:20.990 --> 00:57:25.460 align:middle line:84%
And they fund, depending
upon the library,

00:57:25.460 --> 00:57:27.380 align:middle line:90%
various aspects of the work.

00:57:27.380 --> 00:57:28.250 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: OK.

00:57:28.250 --> 00:57:31.460 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO:
But the government

00:57:31.460 --> 00:57:35.000 align:middle line:84%
work of maintaining
the records, that's

00:57:35.000 --> 00:57:36.500 align:middle line:90%
paid for by the government.

00:57:36.500 --> 00:57:38.090 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: OK.

00:57:38.090 --> 00:57:41.260 align:middle line:84%
What is the process
for requesting access

00:57:41.260 --> 00:57:44.418 align:middle line:90%
to restricted materials?

00:57:44.418 --> 00:57:46.960 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: It depends on
what the restricted material is

00:57:46.960 --> 00:57:51.460 align:middle line:84%
and what the requirements
are for access.

00:57:51.460 --> 00:57:54.850 align:middle line:90%
You can file a FOIA request.

00:57:54.850 --> 00:58:02.320 align:middle line:84%
And one of the ways to expedite
that FOIA request, if you're

00:58:02.320 --> 00:58:04.360 align:middle line:84%
having trouble with
your FOIA request,

00:58:04.360 --> 00:58:08.530 align:middle line:84%
there is a little
known organization

00:58:08.530 --> 00:58:11.290 align:middle line:84%
unit within the
National Archives

00:58:11.290 --> 00:58:13.863 align:middle line:84%
called the Office of Government
Information Services--

00:58:13.863 --> 00:58:15.530 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: I have
to write that down.

00:58:15.530 --> 00:58:17.800 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: --which
is the FOIA ombudsman,

00:58:17.800 --> 00:58:24.020 align:middle line:84%
which serves to facilitate
access for the American public.

00:58:24.020 --> 00:58:28.300 align:middle line:84%
So if you're having
trouble with the FBI

00:58:28.300 --> 00:58:31.930 align:middle line:84%
and having your
request honored, you

00:58:31.930 --> 00:58:38.330 align:middle line:84%
can work with my staff
and OTIS to expedite it.

00:58:38.330 --> 00:58:39.590 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: OK.

00:58:39.590 --> 00:58:40.940 align:middle line:90%
Can I ask a related question--

00:58:40.940 --> 00:58:44.210 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: All of the FOIA
folks in all of the agencies,

00:58:44.210 --> 00:58:46.340 align:middle line:84%
and I can tell you this
from personal experience,

00:58:46.340 --> 00:58:47.810 align:middle line:90%
are overworked.

00:58:47.810 --> 00:58:50.580 align:middle line:84%
There aren't enough people
handling FOIA requests.

00:58:50.580 --> 00:58:52.280 align:middle line:90%
It's a huge problem

00:58:52.280 --> 00:58:57.380 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah, I recently
attended an online forum

00:58:57.380 --> 00:59:00.440 align:middle line:84%
on the mandatory
declassification review

00:59:00.440 --> 00:59:05.840 align:middle line:84%
process, and they said something
like, the vast majority of FOIA

00:59:05.840 --> 00:59:11.450 align:middle line:84%
requests come from only a
very small number of agencies

00:59:11.450 --> 00:59:12.590 align:middle line:90%
or people, essentially.

00:59:12.590 --> 00:59:15.980 align:middle line:84%
And that they make so many
requests that it clogs up

00:59:15.980 --> 00:59:18.680 align:middle line:90%
the system a lot.

00:59:18.680 --> 00:59:20.300 align:middle line:84%
And then a related
question to that

00:59:20.300 --> 00:59:23.900 align:middle line:84%
too and along the lines
of what I just asked,

00:59:23.900 --> 00:59:27.772 align:middle line:84%
is restricted materials but
also classified materials--

00:59:27.772 --> 00:59:28.730 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: [GASPS]

00:59:28.730 --> 00:59:30.320 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

00:59:30.320 --> 00:59:35.160 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Because you
said, with sunshine week,

00:59:35.160 --> 00:59:37.410 align:middle line:84%
the open government
celebration, you

00:59:37.410 --> 00:59:41.850 align:middle line:84%
mentioned that the whole
point of the open government

00:59:41.850 --> 00:59:45.480 align:middle line:84%
is transparency and avoiding
unnecessary secrecy.

00:59:45.480 --> 00:59:49.680 align:middle line:84%
But I think several people
think of classification

00:59:49.680 --> 00:59:53.070 align:middle line:84%
and classified documents as
that unnecessary secrecy.

00:59:53.070 --> 00:59:55.740 align:middle line:84%
So who decides if
it's classified

00:59:55.740 --> 00:59:57.020 align:middle line:90%
and how do you declassify it?

00:59:57.020 --> 00:59:58.800 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO:
It's a real issue.

00:59:58.800 --> 01:00:01.950 align:middle line:84%
Another little known unit
within the National Archives

01:00:01.950 --> 01:00:04.290 align:middle line:84%
is the Information
Security Oversight Office,

01:00:04.290 --> 01:00:06.270 align:middle line:84%
which has responsibility
for overseeing

01:00:06.270 --> 01:00:09.360 align:middle line:84%
all the classification
activity, monitoring it.

01:00:09.360 --> 01:00:15.210 align:middle line:84%
And I can tell you that we
have a huge over classification

01:00:15.210 --> 01:00:19.260 align:middle line:84%
problem within the government
in the executive branch.

01:00:19.260 --> 01:00:25.740 align:middle line:84%
We now have in the neighborhood
of 2,500 original classifiers.

01:00:25.740 --> 01:00:28.230 align:middle line:84%
These are folks who are
authorized to classify.

01:00:28.230 --> 01:00:32.880 align:middle line:84%
This is down from about
9,500 when I started in 2009.

01:00:32.880 --> 01:00:35.610 align:middle line:84%
So we've narrowed
the number of folks

01:00:35.610 --> 01:00:38.910 align:middle line:84%
who have the responsibility
or have the ability.

01:00:38.910 --> 01:00:43.710 align:middle line:84%
There are no standards
among those 2,500 people

01:00:43.710 --> 01:00:46.500 align:middle line:84%
about what is top
secret and what

01:00:46.500 --> 01:00:49.320 align:middle line:90%
might not be classified at all.

01:00:49.320 --> 01:00:52.170 align:middle line:84%
Unlike other countries
who have carved out what

01:00:52.170 --> 01:00:55.650 align:middle line:84%
it means for each of the
classification areas.

01:00:55.650 --> 01:01:00.480 align:middle line:84%
It's coupled with the fact
that the classification process

01:01:00.480 --> 01:01:01.410 align:middle line:90%
is pretty tedious.

01:01:01.410 --> 01:01:05.010 align:middle line:84%
It's line by line,
determining whether it really

01:01:05.010 --> 01:01:06.600 align:middle line:90%
needs to be classified or not.

01:01:06.600 --> 01:01:09.570 align:middle line:84%
And it's easier just to
classify the whole damn document

01:01:09.570 --> 01:01:13.170 align:middle line:90%
than to do that line by line.

01:01:13.170 --> 01:01:18.220 align:middle line:84%
And there was one more piece
of it, of the declassification.

01:01:18.220 --> 01:01:20.163 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah,
I mean, that is also

01:01:20.163 --> 01:01:21.580 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO:
Regardless of what

01:01:21.580 --> 01:01:23.530 align:middle line:84%
you may have read
in the press, it's

01:01:23.530 --> 01:01:26.810 align:middle line:84%
about magic and
waving a magic wand.

01:01:26.810 --> 01:01:28.990 align:middle line:84%
There is a
declassification process.

01:01:28.990 --> 01:01:32.600 align:middle line:84%
Oh, I know what I was going to
say on the classification side.

01:01:32.600 --> 01:01:34.540 align:middle line:84%
Especially in the
intelligence community,

01:01:34.540 --> 01:01:38.590 align:middle line:84%
there are multiple agencies
that have equity in a document.

01:01:38.590 --> 01:01:42.220 align:middle line:84%
So the classification
may have different levels

01:01:42.220 --> 01:01:45.440 align:middle line:84%
of classification within
the same document.

01:01:45.440 --> 01:01:48.610 align:middle line:84%
So that relates to
declassification also.

01:01:48.610 --> 01:01:52.930 align:middle line:84%
So while the president does have
the authority to declassify,

01:01:52.930 --> 01:01:55.220 align:middle line:84%
there is a process
that is followed,

01:01:55.220 --> 01:01:57.970 align:middle line:84%
so that the agencies who did
the original classification

01:01:57.970 --> 01:01:59.192 align:middle line:90%
are notified--

01:01:59.192 --> 01:02:00.400 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: And can object.

01:02:00.400 --> 01:02:02.140 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: --because
that's not the only copy.

01:02:02.140 --> 01:02:03.110 align:middle line:90%
Oh, they can object.

01:02:03.110 --> 01:02:06.670 align:middle line:84%
[LAUGHS] That's
not the only copy

01:02:06.670 --> 01:02:08.050 align:middle line:90%
that sits in the White House.

01:02:08.050 --> 01:02:10.510 align:middle line:84%
The agencies that did the
original classification,

01:02:10.510 --> 01:02:11.710 align:middle line:90%
they have copies also.

01:02:11.710 --> 01:02:14.290 align:middle line:84%
So it's very important
that the agencies

01:02:14.290 --> 01:02:17.750 align:middle line:84%
be notified that that
has been declassified.

01:02:17.750 --> 01:02:20.330 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: And if I
understand this correctly,

01:02:20.330 --> 01:02:25.520 align:middle line:84%
one document can also
have the State Department

01:02:25.520 --> 01:02:26.270 align:middle line:90%
has classified--

01:02:26.270 --> 01:02:27.140 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO:
Multiple equities.

01:02:27.140 --> 01:02:27.890 align:middle line:90%
Yeah, exactly.

01:02:27.890 --> 01:02:31.370 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: --the CIA
has classified part,

01:02:31.370 --> 01:02:33.750 align:middle line:84%
the National Security Agency
has done a different--

01:02:33.750 --> 01:02:35.810 align:middle line:84%
So and all of
those agencies have

01:02:35.810 --> 01:02:39.590 align:middle line:84%
to declassify that particular
portion that they originally

01:02:39.590 --> 01:02:40.270 align:middle line:90%
classified.

01:02:40.270 --> 01:02:40.820 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Yep.

01:02:40.820 --> 01:02:41.150 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Is that?

01:02:41.150 --> 01:02:41.690 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: That's it.

01:02:41.690 --> 01:02:42.690 align:middle line:90%
That's the way it works.

01:02:42.690 --> 01:02:44.030 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah, no.

01:02:44.030 --> 01:02:44.930 align:middle line:90%
Easy-peasy.

01:02:44.930 --> 01:02:46.070 align:middle line:90%
All right.

01:02:46.070 --> 01:02:49.430 align:middle line:84%
Your undergraduate degree
is in English literature.

01:02:49.430 --> 01:02:52.400 align:middle line:84%
Can you speak to how that
degree or course of study

01:02:52.400 --> 01:02:55.310 align:middle line:84%
influenced your career,
if it did at all,

01:02:55.310 --> 01:02:58.910 align:middle line:84%
and/or the broader role of
education in the humanities

01:02:58.910 --> 01:03:01.700 align:middle line:84%
in preparing people for
careers in information and/or

01:03:01.700 --> 01:03:04.790 align:middle line:90%
public service.

01:03:04.790 --> 01:03:07.700 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: I was
originally an education major.

01:03:07.700 --> 01:03:12.350 align:middle line:84%
I always thought I was going
to teach when I first went

01:03:12.350 --> 01:03:14.030 align:middle line:90%
to Northeastern University.

01:03:14.030 --> 01:03:20.970 align:middle line:84%
And the education
courses were just so bad

01:03:20.970 --> 01:03:22.763 align:middle line:90%
that I dropped out of school.

01:03:22.763 --> 01:03:23.430 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Oh

01:03:23.430 --> 01:03:24.305 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Yeah.

01:03:24.305 --> 01:03:26.490 align:middle line:84%
I Joined the Navy,
and when I came back,

01:03:26.490 --> 01:03:30.330 align:middle line:84%
I was a liberal arts major and
had very different attitude

01:03:30.330 --> 01:03:31.590 align:middle line:90%
toward higher education.

01:03:31.590 --> 01:03:35.700 align:middle line:84%
And took courses that
were meaningful to me

01:03:35.700 --> 01:03:38.760 align:middle line:84%
and a wide range across
history, and literature,

01:03:38.760 --> 01:03:41.640 align:middle line:84%
and political science,
and psychology.

01:03:41.640 --> 01:03:45.540 align:middle line:84%
And it was a well rounded
education which, I think,

01:03:45.540 --> 01:03:49.870 align:middle line:84%
gave me an important basis
for higher education,

01:03:49.870 --> 01:03:52.530 align:middle line:90%
but also thinking about careers.

01:03:52.530 --> 01:03:57.450 align:middle line:84%
And at the same time I was
working in my co-op position

01:03:57.450 --> 01:04:01.230 align:middle line:84%
as a junior library
assistant in the libraries

01:04:01.230 --> 01:04:05.100 align:middle line:84%
at MIT, which exposed me to
all kinds of opportunities

01:04:05.100 --> 01:04:06.240 align:middle line:90%
about library work.

01:04:06.240 --> 01:04:08.020 align:middle line:84%
So it was the
combination of the two,

01:04:08.020 --> 01:04:11.287 align:middle line:84%
I think, that put
me where I am today.

01:04:11.287 --> 01:04:12.370 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: I like that.

01:04:12.370 --> 01:04:16.890 align:middle line:84%
So you went from a junior
library position to working--

01:04:16.890 --> 01:04:18.640 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: They
knew they had someone

01:04:18.640 --> 01:04:20.320 align:middle line:90%
on the hook when I came.

01:04:20.320 --> 01:04:22.960 align:middle line:84%
Because I just volunteered
to do anything.

01:04:22.960 --> 01:04:26.560 align:middle line:84%
For those of you
who are old enough

01:04:26.560 --> 01:04:32.230 align:middle line:84%
to remember filing in the shelf
list, I was allowed to file--

01:04:32.230 --> 01:04:34.600 align:middle line:84%
me, a [INAUDIBLE]
student, was allowed

01:04:34.600 --> 01:04:38.950 align:middle line:84%
to file in the
Southwest above the rod.

01:04:38.950 --> 01:04:42.520 align:middle line:84%
Which means that someone,
a real professional,

01:04:42.520 --> 01:04:44.800 align:middle line:84%
came behind me and checked
my work to pull the rod

01:04:44.800 --> 01:04:45.950 align:middle line:90%
and drop the cart.

01:04:45.950 --> 01:04:47.980 align:middle line:84%
So I wasn't doing
the filing, actually.

01:04:47.980 --> 01:04:49.120 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Oh, I see.

01:04:49.120 --> 01:04:50.050 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

01:04:50.050 --> 01:04:55.810 align:middle line:84%
But you went from that to MIT,
and Duke, and the New York

01:04:55.810 --> 01:04:59.563 align:middle line:84%
Public Library, and the
Archivist of the United States.

01:04:59.563 --> 01:05:00.730 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: That's right

01:05:00.730 --> 01:05:01.150 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Yeah.

01:05:01.150 --> 01:05:01.983 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Hmm.

01:05:01.983 --> 01:05:03.250 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

01:05:03.250 --> 01:05:04.510 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Amazing.

01:05:04.510 --> 01:05:08.830 align:middle line:84%
How do you view the new trend
of increased book banning

01:05:08.830 --> 01:05:12.310 align:middle line:84%
and censorship, and
in what ways could it

01:05:12.310 --> 01:05:16.928 align:middle line:84%
affect how our public
records are maintained?

01:05:16.928 --> 01:05:18.470 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: It's
a good question.

01:05:18.470 --> 01:05:21.850 align:middle line:84%
I think that it's just
a horrible situation.

01:05:21.850 --> 01:05:28.140 align:middle line:84%
And I feel badly for
especially school librarians,

01:05:28.140 --> 01:05:31.680 align:middle line:84%
who are the targets
of a lot of this--

01:05:31.680 --> 01:05:35.640 align:middle line:84%
and some public
librarians, also.

01:05:35.640 --> 01:05:38.266 align:middle line:90%
It's hard for me to imagine.

01:05:38.266 --> 01:05:39.630 align:middle line:90%
No, I guess it's not hard.

01:05:39.630 --> 01:05:41.580 align:middle line:90%
Anything, anything can happen.

01:05:41.580 --> 01:05:45.690 align:middle line:84%
In terms of the
way records might

01:05:45.690 --> 01:05:50.760 align:middle line:84%
be influenced, the way the
process works is that there

01:05:50.760 --> 01:05:54.210 align:middle line:84%
are records managers
in each of the agencies

01:05:54.210 --> 01:05:57.360 align:middle line:84%
who are responsible
for overseeing

01:05:57.360 --> 01:06:00.120 align:middle line:84%
all the regulations about
creation and maintenance

01:06:00.120 --> 01:06:01.300 align:middle line:90%
of records.

01:06:01.300 --> 01:06:07.320 align:middle line:84%
So these are career
civil servants.

01:06:07.320 --> 01:06:12.520 align:middle line:84%
They report, however,
to their agencies.

01:06:12.520 --> 01:06:14.400 align:middle line:84%
It's something that
has bothered me,

01:06:14.400 --> 01:06:16.950 align:middle line:84%
and in fact, I made
recommendations

01:06:16.950 --> 01:06:20.010 align:middle line:84%
that all of the
records folks should

01:06:20.010 --> 01:06:21.330 align:middle line:90%
be reporting to the archives.

01:06:21.330 --> 01:06:24.510 align:middle line:90%


01:06:24.510 --> 01:06:28.480 align:middle line:84%
Like the model that's used for
the Inspector General community

01:06:28.480 --> 01:06:30.250 align:middle line:90%
within the federal government.

01:06:30.250 --> 01:06:33.040 align:middle line:84%
They sit in the
agencies, but they

01:06:33.040 --> 01:06:38.650 align:middle line:84%
report to a central
Inspector General Agency.

01:06:38.650 --> 01:06:43.240 align:middle line:84%
There has been, and I can point
to several examples of bias

01:06:43.240 --> 01:06:47.860 align:middle line:84%
in record keeping
in various agencies.

01:06:47.860 --> 01:06:51.100 align:middle line:84%
Because of the
presidential appointment

01:06:51.100 --> 01:06:57.850 align:middle line:84%
at the head of the Agency hiding
information or withholding

01:06:57.850 --> 01:06:58.850 align:middle line:90%
information.

01:06:58.850 --> 01:07:01.760 align:middle line:84%
And in some cases
changing information.

01:07:01.760 --> 01:07:05.410 align:middle line:84%
So those are things
that would be addressed.

01:07:05.410 --> 01:07:07.690 align:middle line:84%
I think if that
records manager was

01:07:07.690 --> 01:07:09.520 align:middle line:84%
more comfortable in
reporting it out.

01:07:09.520 --> 01:07:10.795 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Right, and
had some accountability.

01:07:10.795 --> 01:07:11.795 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Exactly.

01:07:11.795 --> 01:07:14.440 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: And
somebody who could

01:07:14.440 --> 01:07:18.010 align:middle line:90%
notice that and correct it.

01:07:18.010 --> 01:07:21.700 align:middle line:84%
In terms of preservation,
while it is currently

01:07:21.700 --> 01:07:24.250 align:middle line:84%
out of the capacity
for any authority

01:07:24.250 --> 01:07:26.740 align:middle line:84%
to store absolutely
everything, do

01:07:26.740 --> 01:07:30.400 align:middle line:84%
you think private corporations
have a responsibility

01:07:30.400 --> 01:07:33.322 align:middle line:90%
to preserve?

01:07:33.322 --> 01:07:36.575 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: Preserve their
own records, or preserve what?

01:07:36.575 --> 01:07:37.950 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: So
I will continue.

01:07:37.950 --> 01:07:38.310 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Oh.

01:07:38.310 --> 01:07:38.850 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHS]

01:07:38.850 --> 01:07:41.790 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: Do you think that
a website such as YouTube, one

01:07:41.790 --> 01:07:44.880 align:middle line:84%
full of audio books, news
reports, historical footage,

01:07:44.880 --> 01:07:49.170 align:middle line:84%
rare media, tutorials, cultural
touchstones, et cetera,

01:07:49.170 --> 01:07:52.950 align:middle line:84%
has a responsibility to
maintain these archives,

01:07:52.950 --> 01:07:54.870 align:middle line:84%
as they have inserted
themselves as such

01:07:54.870 --> 01:07:57.365 align:middle line:84%
an important feature of the
modern world in other ways?

01:07:57.365 --> 01:07:58.990 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: That's
a good question.

01:07:58.990 --> 01:08:00.008 align:middle line:84%
SARA STEFANI: That
is a good one.

01:08:00.008 --> 01:08:00.883 align:middle line:90%
DAVID FERRIERO: Yeah.

01:08:00.883 --> 01:08:03.430 align:middle line:90%


01:08:03.430 --> 01:08:04.120 align:middle line:90%
Sure.

01:08:04.120 --> 01:08:04.773 align:middle line:90%
Yes.

01:08:04.773 --> 01:08:05.440 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: OK

01:08:05.440 --> 01:08:06.395 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

01:08:06.395 --> 01:08:08.020 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: Let's
make that happen.

01:08:08.020 --> 01:08:08.950 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: OK.

01:08:08.950 --> 01:08:10.210 align:middle line:90%
I like it.

01:08:10.210 --> 01:08:12.670 align:middle line:90%
I mean, Yeah.

01:08:12.670 --> 01:08:17.319 align:middle line:84%
I mean, I'm sort of struck,
and the details are fuzzy,

01:08:17.319 --> 01:08:21.910 align:middle line:84%
but I know that there was an
incident not long ago where--

01:08:21.910 --> 01:08:24.910 align:middle line:84%
I think it was
maybe in Ukraine--

01:08:24.910 --> 01:08:29.140 align:middle line:84%
but somebody had posted
something and then immediately

01:08:29.140 --> 01:08:30.189 align:middle line:90%
taken it down.

01:08:30.189 --> 01:08:32.859 align:middle line:84%
But it was still in
the internet archives,

01:08:32.859 --> 01:08:37.300 align:middle line:84%
and that was the only place that
had whatever this statement was

01:08:37.300 --> 01:08:40.359 align:middle line:84%
or this document that was
put up online and immediately

01:08:40.359 --> 01:08:41.810 align:middle line:90%
taken down.

01:08:41.810 --> 01:08:49.065 align:middle line:84%
So I think this question of,
you have things on YouTube

01:08:49.065 --> 01:08:51.729 align:middle line:84%
and whether they have
that responsibility

01:08:51.729 --> 01:08:53.689 align:middle line:84%
as part of the record
is an interesting one.

01:08:53.689 --> 01:08:55.210 align:middle line:90%
So.

01:08:55.210 --> 01:08:55.848 align:middle line:90%
All right--

01:08:55.848 --> 01:08:57.640 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: Can I
just share two things

01:08:57.640 --> 01:08:59.512 align:middle line:84%
that I brought this
notebook to share.

01:08:59.512 --> 01:09:00.220 align:middle line:90%
SARA STEFANI: Oh.

01:09:00.220 --> 01:09:02.303 align:middle line:84%
DAVID FERRIERO: This thing
about access to records

01:09:02.303 --> 01:09:03.399 align:middle line:90%
is something that--

01:09:03.399 --> 01:09:06.010 align:middle line:84%
it wasn't until 1934
that legislation

01:09:06.010 --> 01:09:08.229 align:middle line:84%
was signed to create
the National Archives,

01:09:08.229 --> 01:09:11.410 align:middle line:84%
but the worry about
access to records

01:09:11.410 --> 01:09:14.020 align:middle line:84%
goes way back to
the very beginning.

01:09:14.020 --> 01:09:19.450 align:middle line:84%
And I got two letters from
Thomas Jefferson on this topic.

01:09:19.450 --> 01:09:22.870 align:middle line:84%
In 1789, he wrote
that, "Whenever

01:09:22.870 --> 01:09:24.640 align:middle line:84%
the people are
well informed, they

01:09:24.640 --> 01:09:26.470 align:middle line:84%
can be trusted with
their own government.

01:09:26.470 --> 01:09:28.779 align:middle line:84%
That whenever things
go so far wrong

01:09:28.779 --> 01:09:32.020 align:middle line:84%
as to attract their notice,
they may be relied on

01:09:32.020 --> 01:09:33.790 align:middle line:90%
to set them to rights."

01:09:33.790 --> 01:09:37.029 align:middle line:90%
And then in 1791.

01:09:37.029 --> 01:09:38.140 align:middle line:90%
That was 1789.

01:09:38.140 --> 01:09:42.430 align:middle line:84%
In 1791 he said, "Time and
accident are committing

01:09:42.430 --> 01:09:45.910 align:middle line:84%
daily havoc on the valuable
historical and state papers

01:09:45.910 --> 01:09:47.740 align:middle line:90%
you have--

01:09:47.740 --> 01:09:48.460 align:middle line:90%
I'm sorry.

01:09:48.460 --> 01:09:50.740 align:middle line:84%
"Time and accident are
committing daily havoc

01:09:50.740 --> 01:09:53.710 align:middle line:84%
on the originals deposited
in our public offices.

01:09:53.710 --> 01:09:57.460 align:middle line:84%
The late war has done the work
of centuries in this business.

01:09:57.460 --> 01:09:59.240 align:middle line:90%
The lost cannot be recovered.

01:09:59.240 --> 01:10:03.520 align:middle line:84%
But let us save what remains,
not by vaults and locks which

01:10:03.520 --> 01:10:05.780 align:middle line:84%
fence them from the
public eye and use

01:10:05.780 --> 01:10:08.190 align:middle line:84%
and consigning them
to the waste of time.

01:10:08.190 --> 01:10:11.210 align:middle line:84%
But by such multiplication
of copies as

01:10:11.210 --> 01:10:13.850 align:middle line:84%
shall place them beyond
the reach of accident."

01:10:13.850 --> 01:10:15.890 align:middle line:90%
Multiplication of copies.

01:10:15.890 --> 01:10:18.935 align:middle line:84%
He is the grandfather
of my digitization work.

01:10:18.935 --> 01:10:20.110 align:middle line:90%
[LAUGHTER]

01:10:20.110 --> 01:10:21.590 align:middle line:90%
Multiplication of copies.

01:10:21.590 --> 01:10:24.410 align:middle line:84%
And then Franklin Roosevelt,
when he was dedicating

01:10:24.410 --> 01:10:27.650 align:middle line:90%
the Presidential Library said--

01:10:27.650 --> 01:10:30.350 align:middle line:84%
he dedicated the
dedication of the library

01:10:30.350 --> 01:10:31.790 align:middle line:90%
as an act of faith--

01:10:31.790 --> 01:10:33.837 align:middle line:84%
"To bring together the
records of the past

01:10:33.837 --> 01:10:35.420 align:middle line:84%
and to house them
into buildings where

01:10:35.420 --> 01:10:37.610 align:middle line:84%
they will be preserved for
the use of men and women

01:10:37.610 --> 01:10:38.570 align:middle line:90%
in the future.

01:10:38.570 --> 01:10:40.700 align:middle line:84%
A nation must believe
in three things.

01:10:40.700 --> 01:10:42.110 align:middle line:90%
It must believe in the past.

01:10:42.110 --> 01:10:44.010 align:middle line:90%
It must believe in the future.

01:10:44.010 --> 01:10:47.730 align:middle line:84%
It must, above all, believe in
the capacity of its own people.

01:10:47.730 --> 01:10:50.960 align:middle line:84%
So to learn from the past
that they can gain in judgment

01:10:50.960 --> 01:10:53.010 align:middle line:90%
in creating their own future."

01:10:53.010 --> 01:10:55.594 align:middle line:90%
So that's what it's all about.

01:10:55.594 --> 01:10:59.490 align:middle line:90%
[APPLAUSE]

01:10:59.490 --> 01:11:07.300 align:middle line:90%


01:11:07.300 --> 01:11:08.890 align:middle line:84%
DINA KELLAMS: That
was so wonderful.

01:11:08.890 --> 01:11:11.140 align:middle line:90%
Sarah, thank you so much.

01:11:11.140 --> 01:11:13.710 align:middle line:84%
On behalf of the Indiana
University Archives,

01:11:13.710 --> 01:11:15.400 align:middle line:84%
and the Indiana
University Libraries,

01:11:15.400 --> 01:11:17.530 align:middle line:84%
and all of our
partners, I just want

01:11:17.530 --> 01:11:19.910 align:middle line:84%
to thank everybody who
made this event possible.

01:11:19.910 --> 01:11:22.630 align:middle line:84%
Particularly the IU
library staff members,

01:11:22.630 --> 01:11:26.140 align:middle line:84%
who work behind the scenes
to ensure that everything

01:11:26.140 --> 01:11:28.150 align:middle line:90%
runs like a well-oiled machine.

01:11:28.150 --> 01:11:31.870 align:middle line:84%
It's amazing to have colleagues
who welcome your ideas

01:11:31.870 --> 01:11:34.480 align:middle line:84%
and figure out how they
can help them succeed.

01:11:34.480 --> 01:11:37.090 align:middle line:84%
Thank you to Dr. Sara
Stefani for serving

01:11:37.090 --> 01:11:41.470 align:middle line:84%
as our very capable and very
informed moderator tonight.

01:11:41.470 --> 01:11:42.580 align:middle line:90%
This is how old I am.

01:11:42.580 --> 01:11:45.070 align:middle line:90%
I'm ready to go to bed already.

01:11:45.070 --> 01:11:46.880 align:middle line:90%
And Thank you all for attending.

01:11:46.880 --> 01:11:48.430 align:middle line:84%
And Thank you,
David, for joining us

01:11:48.430 --> 01:11:51.280 align:middle line:90%
at Indiana University this week.

01:11:51.280 --> 01:11:53.500 align:middle line:84%
The libraries would
like to send you home

01:11:53.500 --> 01:11:57.220 align:middle line:84%
with one of our most popular
Indiana University Press books.

01:11:57.220 --> 01:12:00.100 align:middle line:84%
However, this will put you

01:12:00.100 --> 01:12:01.570 align:middle line:90%
So we will mail it to you.

[LAUGHTER]

01:12:03.200 --> 01:12:05.930 align:middle line:84%
And with that, we will
conclude today's event.

01:12:05.930 --> 01:12:07.760 align:middle line:84%
Thank you, everybody,
for coming today.

01:12:07.760 --> 01:12:11.110 align:middle line:90%
[APPLAUSE]

WEBVTT

00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:00.300 align:middle line:90%


00:00:00.300 --> 00:00:01.550 align:middle line:90%
DIANE DALLIS-COMENTALE: Hello.

00:00:01.550 --> 00:00:02.050 align:middle line:90%
OK.

00:00:02.050 --> 00:00:03.710 align:middle line:90%
Just checking.

00:00:03.710 --> 00:00:05.310 align:middle line:90%
Welcome everyone.

00:00:05.310 --> 00:00:07.050 align:middle line:90%
Good afternoon.

00:00:07.050 --> 00:00:11.390 align:middle line:84%
I'm Diane Dallis-Comentale,
Ruth Lilly Dean of IU Libraries.

00:00:11.390 --> 00:00:13.550 align:middle line:84%
Indiana University
has championed

00:00:13.550 --> 00:00:16.280 align:middle line:84%
libraries and archives
of diverse collections

00:00:16.280 --> 00:00:18.290 align:middle line:84%
which have been
developed over centuries

00:00:18.290 --> 00:00:20.840 align:middle line:84%
by expert librarians,
researchers, archivists,

00:00:20.840 --> 00:00:22.070 align:middle line:90%
and curators.

00:00:22.070 --> 00:00:24.440 align:middle line:84%
As a librarian, I
have the privilege

00:00:24.440 --> 00:00:26.480 align:middle line:84%
of leading one of the
top research library

00:00:26.480 --> 00:00:28.680 align:middle line:90%
systems in North America.

00:00:28.680 --> 00:00:31.940 align:middle line:84%
My role requires me to
simultaneously consider

00:00:31.940 --> 00:00:35.000 align:middle line:84%
the past and the future, and
constantly keep those things

00:00:35.000 --> 00:00:36.350 align:middle line:90%
in the balance.

00:00:36.350 --> 00:00:39.050 align:middle line:84%
I ask that we pause
for a moment to think

00:00:39.050 --> 00:00:41.300 align:middle line:84%
about all that has
come before us,

00:00:41.300 --> 00:00:44.660 align:middle line:84%
and all those who made it
possible for us to be here,

00:00:44.660 --> 00:00:46.190 align:middle line:90%
together, today.

00:00:46.190 --> 00:00:49.370 align:middle line:84%
Indiana University was built
on Indigenous homelands

00:00:49.370 --> 00:00:50.450 align:middle line:90%
and resources.

00:00:50.450 --> 00:00:52.550 align:middle line:84%
With deep respect
and appreciation,

00:00:52.550 --> 00:00:56.340 align:middle line:84%
I acknowledge the Indigenous
nations' communities, families,

00:00:56.340 --> 00:01:00.780 align:middle line:84%
and especially those of the
Miami, Delaware, Potawatomi,

00:01:00.780 --> 00:01:02.340 align:middle line:90%
and Shawnee people.

00:01:02.340 --> 00:01:04.830 align:middle line:84%
The Foundation of our
state and our University

00:01:04.830 --> 00:01:08.280 align:middle line:84%
was built on unceded land
by indentured laborers,

00:01:08.280 --> 00:01:11.670 align:middle line:84%
immigrants, and many people
who endured and struggled

00:01:11.670 --> 00:01:14.820 align:middle line:84%
those whose names
and lives have often

00:01:14.820 --> 00:01:17.160 align:middle line:90%
been forgotten by history.

00:01:17.160 --> 00:01:20.640 align:middle line:84%
With this in mind, before
our program starts,

00:01:20.640 --> 00:01:23.400 align:middle line:84%
I hope that you consider the
opportunity and privilege we

00:01:23.400 --> 00:01:26.050 align:middle line:90%
all share in being here today.

00:01:26.050 --> 00:01:28.770 align:middle line:84%
All who have come
before us, all who

00:01:28.770 --> 00:01:32.160 align:middle line:84%
have made it possible
to be here today,

00:01:32.160 --> 00:01:36.600 align:middle line:84%
open to a conversation
across many generations

00:01:36.600 --> 00:01:39.430 align:middle line:84%
and with many new
ideas coming together.

00:01:39.430 --> 00:01:41.790 align:middle line:84%
This is a privilege
we share, and I really

00:01:41.790 --> 00:01:43.920 align:middle line:84%
appreciate your thoughts
about that as you go

00:01:43.920 --> 00:01:45.850 align:middle line:90%
through the rest of your day.

00:01:45.850 --> 00:01:49.020 align:middle line:84%
So on behalf of
our partners, I am

00:01:49.020 --> 00:01:52.950 align:middle line:84%
thrilled by your interest in
the significance of archives

00:01:52.950 --> 00:01:54.840 align:middle line:84%
and the role of the
national government.

00:01:54.840 --> 00:01:58.500 align:middle line:84%
It is an honor for IU to host
this discussion as we kick off

00:01:58.500 --> 00:02:01.710 align:middle line:84%
American Archives Month
as well as a month

00:02:01.710 --> 00:02:04.150 align:middle line:84%
celebrating archives of
the state of Indiana.

00:02:04.150 --> 00:02:07.770 align:middle line:84%
Thanks to a formal
proclamation by our governor.

00:02:07.770 --> 00:02:10.979 align:middle line:84%
Our partners for this gathering
are listed on the screen above.

00:02:10.979 --> 00:02:12.840 align:middle line:84%
Though, I am specifically
calling attention

00:02:12.840 --> 00:02:14.490 align:middle line:84%
to our friends at
the Luddy School

00:02:14.490 --> 00:02:17.310 align:middle line:84%
of Informatics Department
of Information and Library

00:02:17.310 --> 00:02:20.220 align:middle line:84%
Science, the Hamilton
Lugar School of Global

00:02:20.220 --> 00:02:23.250 align:middle line:84%
and International Studies,
and the Paul O'Neill

00:02:23.250 --> 00:02:26.040 align:middle line:84%
School of Public and
Environmental Affairs.

00:02:26.040 --> 00:02:30.345 align:middle line:84%
If you are here as part of
the fall 2023 Themester, Lux

00:02:30.345 --> 00:02:33.390 align:middle line:84%
et Veritas, you deserve
a special welcome.

00:02:33.390 --> 00:02:35.790 align:middle line:84%
Thank you to the College
of Arts and Sciences

00:02:35.790 --> 00:02:37.920 align:middle line:84%
for more than a
decade of engaged

00:02:37.920 --> 00:02:41.460 align:middle line:84%
learning through the exceptional
issues based Themester

00:02:41.460 --> 00:02:43.620 align:middle line:90%
teaching and programming.

00:02:43.620 --> 00:02:47.790 align:middle line:84%
It turns out that this
year's Themester theme, light

00:02:47.790 --> 00:02:50.400 align:middle line:84%
and truth, was quite
inspirational to my colleague

00:02:50.400 --> 00:02:52.830 align:middle line:84%
Dina Kellams, Director
of University Archives,

00:02:52.830 --> 00:02:56.190 align:middle line:84%
and the incredible team
of archivists she leads.

00:02:56.190 --> 00:02:58.530 align:middle line:84%
When they first began
discussing and planning

00:02:58.530 --> 00:03:06.350 align:middle line:84%
this year's activities,
they knew right away

00:03:06.350 --> 00:03:09.470 align:middle line:84%
that the person they
wanted to have come,

00:03:09.470 --> 00:03:11.630 align:middle line:84%
who could best
illustrate and illuminate

00:03:11.630 --> 00:03:16.190 align:middle line:84%
how important archives are,
is our former Archivist

00:03:16.190 --> 00:03:18.710 align:middle line:84%
of the United States,
David Ferriero.

00:03:18.710 --> 00:03:20.810 align:middle line:84%
In a moment I will
hand over the stage

00:03:20.810 --> 00:03:22.970 align:middle line:84%
to Sara Stefani one
of the IU Library's

00:03:22.970 --> 00:03:25.640 align:middle line:84%
many outstanding archivists,
who will be moderating

00:03:25.640 --> 00:03:27.320 align:middle line:90%
this discussion today.

00:03:27.320 --> 00:03:28.880 align:middle line:90%
Sara is the modical--

00:03:28.880 --> 00:03:30.860 align:middle line:84%
political-- modern--
I'm so sorry.

00:03:30.860 --> 00:03:33.560 align:middle line:84%
Modern Political Papers
Archivist and she

00:03:33.560 --> 00:03:36.050 align:middle line:84%
joined the IU Libraries
in 2018 to work

00:03:36.050 --> 00:03:40.460 align:middle line:84%
on the papers of the longtime
Indiana Senator, Richard Lugar.

00:03:40.460 --> 00:03:43.670 align:middle line:84%
Sara received her doctorate
from Yale University

00:03:43.670 --> 00:03:46.790 align:middle line:84%
in Slavic languages
and literature.

00:03:46.790 --> 00:03:50.450 align:middle line:84%
She oversees our collections
of papers from Congresswoman,

00:03:50.450 --> 00:03:54.290 align:middle line:84%
Jill Long Thompson, Senator
Birch Bayh, and Congressman Lee

00:03:54.290 --> 00:03:56.390 align:middle line:90%
Hamilton, among many others.

00:03:56.390 --> 00:03:59.360 align:middle line:84%
She is a member of the steering
committee of the Congressional

00:03:59.360 --> 00:04:03.480 align:middle line:84%
Papers Section of the
American Society of Archivist,

00:04:03.480 --> 00:04:06.600 align:middle line:84%
and the president of the
Association of Centers

00:04:06.600 --> 00:04:08.460 align:middle line:90%
for the Study of Congress.

00:04:08.460 --> 00:04:11.400 align:middle line:84%
Sarah will be leading the
question and answer session

00:04:11.400 --> 00:04:14.670 align:middle line:84%
with our distinguished
guest, David Ferriero, who

00:04:14.670 --> 00:04:17.160 align:middle line:84%
served as the 10th archivist
of the United States

00:04:17.160 --> 00:04:20.880 align:middle line:90%
from 2009 through April 2022.

00:04:20.880 --> 00:04:24.330 align:middle line:84%
President Barack Obama
nominated Mr Ferriero,

00:04:24.330 --> 00:04:26.370 align:middle line:84%
who was confirmed
by the US Senate

00:04:26.370 --> 00:04:29.130 align:middle line:90%
and sworn in November of 2020--

00:04:29.130 --> 00:04:30.870 align:middle line:90%
sorry, 2009.

00:04:30.870 --> 00:04:34.230 align:middle line:84%
As archivist, Mr Ferriero
oversaw the addition

00:04:34.230 --> 00:04:37.170 align:middle line:84%
of three new
presidential libraries

00:04:37.170 --> 00:04:41.940 align:middle line:84%
to the National Archives
and Records Administration

00:04:41.940 --> 00:04:45.090 align:middle line:90%
Presidential Library systems.

00:04:45.090 --> 00:04:47.010 align:middle line:84%
Before leading the
National Archives,

00:04:47.010 --> 00:04:50.580 align:middle line:84%
Mr Ferriero served as
Andrew W. Mellon, director

00:04:50.580 --> 00:04:52.200 align:middle line:90%
of New York Public Library.

00:04:52.200 --> 00:04:53.970 align:middle line:84%
He was part of the
leadership team

00:04:53.970 --> 00:04:58.050 align:middle line:84%
responsible for integrating the
four research libraries and 87

00:04:58.050 --> 00:05:01.390 align:middle line:84%
branches to create the
largest public library

00:05:01.390 --> 00:05:04.540 align:middle line:84%
system in the United States
and one of the largest research

00:05:04.540 --> 00:05:06.100 align:middle line:90%
libraries in the world.

00:05:06.100 --> 00:05:10.330 align:middle line:84%
Mr Ferriero served in
top leadership positions

00:05:10.330 --> 00:05:13.390 align:middle line:84%
in two of the nation's
highly ranked universities,

00:05:13.390 --> 00:05:16.190 align:middle line:84%
the Massachusetts Institute
of Technology in Cambridge,

00:05:16.190 --> 00:05:20.200 align:middle line:84%
Massachusetts, and Duke
University in Durham, North

00:05:20.200 --> 00:05:21.070 align:middle line:90%
Carolina.

00:05:21.070 --> 00:05:25.570 align:middle line:84%
Mr Ferriero earned bachelor's
degrees and master's degrees

00:05:25.570 --> 00:05:28.420 align:middle line:84%
in English Literature from
Northeastern University

00:05:28.420 --> 00:05:32.080 align:middle line:84%
in Boston and a master's degree
from Simmons College of Library

00:05:32.080 --> 00:05:34.510 align:middle line:84%
and Information
Science in Boston.

00:05:34.510 --> 00:05:38.050 align:middle line:84%
Mr Ferriero also served as
a Navy hospital corpsman

00:05:38.050 --> 00:05:39.580 align:middle line:90%
during the Vietnam War.

00:05:39.580 --> 00:05:43.660 align:middle line:84%
Before we jump into
the Q&A our moderator,

00:05:43.660 --> 00:05:46.840 align:middle line:84%
Sara Stefani has a
few details regarding

00:05:46.840 --> 00:05:48.470 align:middle line:90%
audience participation.

00:05:48.470 --> 00:05:50.290 align:middle line:84%
And I'm going to
hand things over

00:05:50.290 --> 00:05:52.360 align:middle line:90%
to Sarah's very capable hands.

00:05:52.360 --> 00:05:54.250 align:middle line:84%
And I sincerely
appreciate all of you

00:05:54.250 --> 00:05:55.450 align:middle line:90%
being in attendance today.

00:05:55.450 --> 00:05:56.670 align:middle line:90%
Thank you.

00:05:56.670 --> 00:06:00.170 align:middle line:90%
[APPLAUSE]

I want to thank everyone
for coming today.
